{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} [[File:Arts District, Las Vegas, United States (Unsplash).jpg|thumb|right|250px|A Pink Cadillac in the Downtown Arts District.]]
The '''Las Vegas Arts District''', or the '''18b''' in [[Downtown Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] was created in 1998 as an 18 block zone set aside to encourage art and artists.<ref>{{cite web | title=Downtown Arts District | url=http://www.fodors.com/world/north-america/usa/nevada/las-vegas/review-178016.html | work=[[Fodor's Travel]] | publisher=[[Random House]] | accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
The district won [[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]'s ''Best of Las Vegas'' award in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|first= Ken |last = White| title=Downtown Arts District finally taking hold | url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/bestoflv/2005/bestartsdistrict.jsp;jsessionid=BMGLLJLEFKAA | work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] | accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
Known as the 18b, the Las Vegas Arts District contains a mix of independent businesses including [[vintage clothing]] boutiques, antique stores, art galleries, hair salons, restaurants, The 18b is located halfway between the Fremont East Entertainment district and the Stratosphere Resort, clustered around Main and Charleston, bounded loosely by Commerce Street to the West, Hoover Avenue to the North, Fourth Street to the East and Wyoming Avenue at the south. It is an easy bike ride, walk or bus ride from Fremont Street. The name, "18b," represents the original Arts District area, which consisted of 18 blocks. Today, the Arts District area has grown beyond those original 18 blocks and is a classic urban mix of residential, commercial and cultural uses that will continue to grow as the hub of the arts scene in Las Vegas.
The "First Friday" Art Walk is a monthly arts and cultural event drawing up to 30,000 visitors into the neighborhood on the first Friday evening of each month. This event encourages people to flock downtown to browse, buy, eat, drink and mingle. The event is a festival environment with food and beverage vendors, music, visual performances and artists/artisans/craftspeople displaying their works.
== Events == The district hosts a ''First Friday'' art walk on the first Friday of every month. First Friday offers an eclectic group of artists as well as "entertainers of all types, including local bands, fire breathers, acrobats, break dancers, fortune tellers and performance artists."<ref>{{cite web | title=Artsy Schmartzy | url=http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/page.aspx?id=148648 | publisher=[[United Jewish Communities]] | accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
In addition to ''First Friday'', Preview Thursday is held preceding night before the block party. It is a subdued night of gallery openings and special events around the arts district without the large crowds that the main event can bring.
== Boundaries == The district is loosely bounded by Hoover Avenue, Wyoming Avenue, [[Las Vegas Boulevard]], and Commerce Street. The official bounds are visible on the ''City of Las Vegas'' website.

{{Infobox person | name = Aleksandr Khanzhonkov | image = Олександр Ханжонков.jpg | birth_name = Aleksandr Aleksejevich Khanzhonkov | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1877|8|8}} | birth_place = Khanzhonkovka, [[Don Host Oblast]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1945|9|26|1877|8|8}} | death_place = [[Yalta]], [[Crimean Oblast]], [[Soviet Union]] | occupation = [[Film producer|Producer]], [[film director]] | years_active = 1905–1926 }} '''Aleksandr Aleksejevich Khanzhonkov''' ({{lang-rus|Александр Алексеевич Ханжонков|p=ɐlʲɪˈksandr ɐlʲɪˈksʲejɪvʲɪtɕ xənˈʐonkəf}}; {{OldStyleDate|8 August|1877|27 July}} — 26 September 1945) was a pioneering [[Russian Empire|Russian]] cinema entrepreneur, film director and screenwriter. He is known for producing ''[[Defence of Sevastopol]]'', Russia's first [[feature film]], as well as [[Ladislas Starevich]]'s ground-breaking [[stop motion]] animation. Khanzhonkov worked as a consultant in the post-revolutionary [[Goskino]] until he was banned from cinema in 1926.<ref name=''rollberg>''Peter Rollberg (2016)''. [https://books.google.ru/books?id=gM6QDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA3 Historical Dictionary of Russian and Soviet Cinema]. — [[Rowman & Littlefield]], p. 3 {{ISBN|978-1-4422-6842-5}}</ref>
==Early Years== Khanzhonkov was born in the small village of Khanzhonkova of the Don Host Oblast (modern-day [[Makiivka]], [[Donetsk Oblast]]) into a [[Russian nobility|noble]] family of [[Don Cossacks]]. His father Alexei Petrovich Khanzhonkov was a landlord who went bankrupt. His mother Paraskeva Sergeevna Khanzhonkova (née Dmitrieva) came from a colonel's family who owned a [[Singer Corporation|Singer]] shop in [[Moscow]]. The noble title was first granted to Aleksandr's great-grandfather Vasily Khanzhonkov.<ref name='orlova'>''Irina Orlova (2007)''. Dedicate My Life to Cinema. — Donetsk: Promin, 127 pages (Biography)</ref><ref>[http://media.ukr-info.net/smi/view_article.cgi?sid=22&nid=2583&aid=29817 Interview with Aleksandr Khanzhonkov's granddaughter Irina Orlova] from the ''[[:ru:Вечерний Донецк|Evening Donetsk]]'' newspaper № 73, May 18, 2007 (in Russian)</ref><ref name='chastny'>Maxim Medvedev. ''[http://www.chaskor.ru/article/aleksandr_hanzhonkov_rab_kinematografa_v_sadu_rashodyashchihsya_tropok_19002 A slave of cinema in the garden of the parting paths]'' article at [[Chastny Korrespondent]], August 8, 2014 (in Russian)</ref>
Aleksandr studied in the [[Novocherkassk]] Cossack School and was sent to serve in the Moscow host after his graduation in 1986. He took part in the [[Russo-Japanese War]] which undermined his health.<ref name='orlova' /><ref name='chastny' /> In 1905, upon a discharge from military training due to health issues, Khanzhonkov sat in on a screening of [[Train Pulling into a Station]] by the [[Lumiere Brothers]].<ref>[https://russiapedia.rt.com/prominent-russians/cinema-and-theater/aleksansdr-khanzhonkov/ Prominent Russians: Aleksansdr Khanzhonkov in ''Russiapedia'']</ref> This marked the onset of his interest and subsequent investment in film, primarily as a producer but also as a director.
==Career== In 1906 Khanzhonkov founded Russia's first cinema factory, A. Khanzhonkov and Co., whose main financial backer was [[Ivan Ozerov]], an influential banker and member of the [[State Council of Imperial Russia|Russian State Council]]. Initial productions were shot on stage in the vein of [[Melies]] and were overshadowed by the work of [[Alexander Drankov]]. Known for his unabashed commercialism, Drankov would remain a competitor up to the revolution of 1917.<ref name=''rollberg /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leyda|first1=Jay|title=Prologue to the Russian Film (Part Two)|journal=Hollywood Quarterly|date=January 1947|volume=2|issue=2|page=171}}</ref>
It wasn't until 1911 that Khanzhonkov's factory would receive widespread acclaim with the release of ''[[Defence of Sevastopol]]''. One of the earliest full length Russian feature films, it was equally notable for its technical aspects. By the end of 1912, Khanzhonkov had established a permanent studio in Moscow and went on to produce over a hundred films over the course of the next several years.<ref>{{cite book|last1=F. Jahn|first1=Hubertus|title=Cultures in Flux|date=1944|publisher=Princeton University Press|page=141|chapter=For Tsar and Fatherland? Russian Popular Culture and the First World War}}</ref><ref name="hand that turns">{{cite journal|last1=Cavendish|first1=Philip|title=The Hand That Turns the Handle: Camera Operators and the Poetics of the Camera in Pre-Revolutionary Russian Film|journal=The Slavonic and East European Review|date=April 2004|volume=82|issue=2|page=214}}</ref> Much of Khanzhonkov's work during this time period went "virtually unseen by the Russian masses" and often took aim at aristocratic sensibilities or adapted great Russian novels of the 19th century.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gaines|first1=Jane|title=Revolutionary Theory/Prerevolutionary Melodrama|journal=Discourse|date=Spring 1995|volume=17|issue=3|page=103}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Tsivian|first1=Yuri|title=Early Cinema in Russian and its Cultural Reception|date=1991|page=132}}</ref> Nonetheless, Khanzhonov helped create many standards in Russian cinema production; the first confirmed use of artificial light in the Russian film industry takes place in a Khanzhonkov documentary piece.<ref name = "hand that turns"/>
During the [[Russian Revolution]], Khanzhonkov fled Russia to [[Constantinople]] and [[Vienna]], and, despite previous affiliation with the royal family, returned upon invitation to the [[USSR]] in 1923 and was appointed director of the new Soviet studio [[Proletkino]] and later as a production consultant for [[Goskino]]. His career in the [[Soviet Union]] ended in 1926: he was forced to abdicate after a corruption scandal struck Proletkino, and never worked in cinema again. Khanzhonkov spent the rest of his life in [[Yalta]], living on a personal pension from the state. There he survived the [[Crimea#In the Soviet Union|Nazi occupation of Crimea]] in 1941–1944, and died in Yalta after many years of declining health on September 26, 1945.
== Bibliography == * Ханжонков, А.А. 1937. ''Ранние годы русской анимации.'' Москва/Ленинград: Искусство. * Кузнецова, М. 1997. ''Александр Ханжонков. Жизнь за кадром.'' Москва: "Профил" No. 29. * Янгиров, Рашит. 2001. ''К биографии А.А. Ханжонкова: Новый ракурс.'' Москва: "Киноведческие записки" No. 55.

{{Infobox person | name = Alexei Davidov | image = Alexei Davidov.JPG | alt = Fuzzy old photo of middle-aged white man in early 19th-century business garb | caption = Alexei Davidov | birth_date = {{Birth date|1867|08|23}}<ref name=yandex>{{cite web |url=http://slovari.yandex.ru/~книги/Музыкальный_словарь/Давидов/ |title=Давидов |trans-title=Davidov |author= |date= |work=Yandex Dictionaries |accessdate=January 30, 2012}} {{language icon|ru}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Moscow]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1940|03|06|1867|08|23}} | death_place = [[Berlin]] | nationality = Russian | occupation = Musician, businessman }} '''Alexei Augustovich Davidov''' ({{lang-ru|'''Алексей Августович Давидов'''}}) (1867-1940) was a Russian cellist and composer, and also a banker, industrialist, and businessman.
Davidov was born in Moscow on August 23, 1867, the son of mathematician and educator [[August Davidov]] originally from [[Courland]]. His uncle [[Karl Davydov|Karl Davidov]] was a cellist and composer, and head of the [[Saint Petersburg Conservatory]].
In 1891 Davidov was graduated from the Faculty of Mathematics and Physics of the [[Saint Petersburg State University|University of Saint Petersburg]] and also from the Saint Petersburg Conservatory with a concentration in cello and composition.
Davidov was a founder and member (from 1894) of the [[Saint Petersburg Music Society]] ({{lang-ru|Петербургского общества музыкальных собраний}}), and in 1896 and 1897 its chairman. He participated in the staging of the operas ''[[The Maid of Pskov]]'' and ''[[Boris Godunov]]''.
Davidov served in the Special Office for Credit in the [[Ministry of Finance of the Russian Empire|Ministry of Finance]] and from the late 1890s was a member of the board of trustees of the [[Saint Petersburg International Bank]]. He was head of the [[Commercial Bank of Saint Petersburg]] from 1909 to 1917, and was a member or chairman of boards of many companies with which the bank was involved, engaged in gold mining, coal mining, machinery manufacturing, and other industries. He was a board member of the Electric Lighting Company (formed in 1886) and that company's Electric Power Division, which built power plants in [[Baku]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ourbaku.com/index.php5/Давидов_Алексей_Августович_-_предприниматель |title=Давидов Алексей Августович - предприниматель |trans-title=Alexei Augustovich Davidov - Entrepreneur |author= |date= |work=Our Baku |accessdate=January 30, 2012}} {{language icon|ru}}</ref>
As head of the Commercial Bank, and working jointly with the [[Russo-Chinese Bank|Russo-Asiatic Bank]], Davidov participated in the creation of various monopolies.
Davidov was a member of the board of the [[Old Saint Petersburg Stock Exchange|Saint Petersburg Stock Exchange]] and, from 1913, a [[Table of Ranks|state councilor]] (a civilian rank equivalent to the military rank of brigadier general).
After the [[Russian Revolution]]s of 1917, Davidov fled to exile in Germany. He became a [[Freemasonry|Freemason]] on February 24, 1922, and died in Berlin on March 6, 1940.
Davidov was married twice, first (in 1895) to the [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] noblewoman Tamara Eristova. His second wife was the [[Mariinsky Theatre]] ballerina [[Eugenie Eduardova|Eugenie Platonovna Eduardova]]. He had three children, Yuri (born 1897), Cyrus (born 1900), and Tatiana (born 1902).
==Works== {{expand list|date=January 2012}} *''The Sunken Bell'' ({{lang-ru|Потонувший колокол}}), opera (1900) *''Sister Beatrice'' ({{lang-ru|Сестра Биатриса}}), opera *''Sextet for Strings, Opus 12'', dedicated to Davidov's brother Ivan<ref>{{cite web|url=http://imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/a/a1/IMSLP34391-PMLP77642-Davidoff.Aleksei.Avgustovich_-_Sextet_Op12_score.pdf |title=Sextuor pour 2 Violons, 2 Altos, et 2 Violoncelles |trans-title=Sextet for 2 Violins, 2 Violas, and 2 Cellos (score) |author=Alexei Davidov |date= |publisher=P. Jurgenson |accessdate=January 30, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{language icon|fr}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://imslp.org/wiki/Category:Davidov,_Aleksei_Avgustovich Alexei Davidov] at the [[International Music Score Library Project]].

[[Washington and Lee University]]
[[Lexington, Virginia]], U.S. |spouse = {{Marriage|[[Henry Lee III]]|1793|1818|reason=died}} |children = 9, including:
[[Henry Lee IV]]
[[Sydney Smith Lee]]
[[Robert E. Lee]]}} '''Anne Hill Carter Lee''' (March 26, 1773 – June 26, 1829) was the wife of the ninth governor of Virginia, [[Henry Lee III]], and the mother of the general-in-chief of the Confederate States of America, [[Robert E. Lee]]. As a separated wife and then as a widow, she was the head of her household at [[Lee Corner]], [[Alexandria, Virginia]], in what is now known as the [[Robert E. Lee Boyhood Home]]. Her chronic pain and straightened circumstances play a significant role in her son Robert's biography.{{cite web |url=https://jgburdette.wordpress.com/2012/09/06/the-disgraced-hero-light-horse-harry-henry-lee/ |title="The Disgraced Hero: 'Light Horse Harry' Henry Lee" |work=J.G. Burdette |accessdate=2016-08-28 |format=}} ==Early life== Anne was born at the family seat, [[Shirley Plantation]] in [[Charles City County, Virginia|Charles City County]], on March 26, 1773. She was born into a patrician family of tidewater Virginia, and was the daughter of Charles Carter (1732–1806), the fifth generation owner of Shirley Plantation, and Anne Butler ([[née]] Moore) Carter (1750–1809).{{cite book |last1=Garber |first1=Virginia Armistead |title=The Armistead family: 1635-1910 |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=21IbAAAAYAAJ |year=1910 |publisher=Whittet & Shepperson Printers |location=Richmond, Virginia|pages=30–33 |chapter=John Armistead: The Second Son of William the Immigrant }} Through her grandfather, John Carter (1690/6–1742),{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Emory G.|title=John Carter (1695 or 1696–1742)|url=http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Carter_John_1695_or_1696-1742|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Virginia]]|accessdate=13 July 2015}} she was the great-granddaughter of [[Robert Carter I|Robert "King" Carter]], the 25th [[Speaker of the Virginia House of Burgesses]] from 1696 to 1697 and the [[List of colonial governors of Virginia|Colonial Governor of Virginia]] from 1726 to 1727.{{cite web |url=http://www.christchurch1735.org/history/robert_carter.html |title=History: Robert "King" Carter of Corotoman (1663-1732) |first= |last= |author=Foundation for Historic Christ Church |work=Historic Christ Church |publisher=Historic Christ Church |location=Lancaster County, Virginia|accessdate=22 December 2010}} ==Marriage== On June 18, 1793, she married the 9th Governor of Virginia, the widower [[Henry Lee III|Henry "Light Horse Harry" Lee]] (1756–1818), in the mansion's parlor. After Lee retired from the governorship in December 1794, she followed him to his Lee family holdings in northern Virginia. Six children were born to this marriage:Pryor, Elizabeth Brown (October 29, 2009). [http://encyclopediavirginia.org/Lee_Robert_Edward_1807-1870 "Robert E. Lee (ca. 1806–1870)"]. [http://encyclopediavirginia.org/ Encyclopedia Virginia]. Retrieved February 18, 2011.{{cite book|last1=Mead|first1=Edward Campbell|title=Genealogical History of the Lee Family of Virginia and Maryland from A.D. 1300 to A.D. 1866|date=1868|publisher=New York : Richardson & Co.|url=https://archive.org/details/genealogicalhist00mead|accessdate=29 January 2018}} * Algernon Sidney Lee (1795–1796), who died in infancy at [[Sully (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Sully]] Plantation, buried there in an unmarked grave.Gamble, Robert S. '' Sully: Biography of a House'' (Sully Foundation Ltd: Chantilly, VA, 1973), p. 40 * Charles Carter Lee (1798–1871), who married Lucy Penn Taylor (1827–1913). * Anne Kinloch Lee (1800–1864), who married William Louis Marshall (1803–1869). * [[Sydney Smith Lee]] (1802–1869), who married Anne Marie Mason (1811–1898) of Virginia. * [[Robert Edward Lee]] (1807–1870), the [[Confederate States of America]] general who married [[Mary Anna Custis Lee|Mary Anna Randolph Custis]] (1808–1873) great-granddaughter of [[Martha Washington]] by her first husband [[Daniel Parke Custis]].{{harvnb|Fellman|2000|pp=24–25}} * Catharine Mildred Lee (1811–1856), who married Edward Vernon Childe (1804–1861). Anne Carter Lee's time as a wealthy patrician of northern Virginia would, however, be short. Their principal plantation, [[Stratford Hall (plantation)|Stratford Hall]], was relinquished in 1808 by [[Fee tail|entail]] to her stepson [[Henry Lee IV]]. Her husband had suffered repeated financial reverses, characterized by poor investments, and was forced to declare bankruptcy in 1809 and move to [[debtor's prison]]. Anne Carter and "Light Horse Harry" were separated for one year while the husband was under confinement. In 1810, the reunited couple tried to resume life together in Alexandria. Despite the fall in his honor and standing, the former governor "Light Horse Harry" had maintained fervent ties to the [[Federalist Party]], and passionately opposed the decision by the other U.S. political party, the [[Democratic-Republican Party|Jeffersonians]], to declare war on Great Britain in the [[War of 1812]]. In a July 1812 outbreak of political violence in Baltimore, [[War hawk|War Hawk]] rioters raided a Federalist strongpoint and tried to lynch its defenders, including Harry Lee. Anne Carter Lee was forced to learn that her husband had suffered serious physical and psychological wounds in the mob outburst. As life for him in Alexandria had become impossible, Henry Lee was forced to leave his wife and family.{{Cite news|url=http://www.womenhistoryblog.com/2011/02/ann-hill-carter-lee.html|title=Anne Carter Lee {{!}} History of American Women|date=2011-02-26|work=History of American Women|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-US}} Lee emigrated to the South Atlantic coast and the Caribbean in a series of futile attempts to find a place to recuperate from his injuries. He died on the Georgia coast on 25 March 1818, leaving Anne Carter Lee a middle-class widow. ===Widowhood=== As a widow and the head of her household, Anne Carter Lee brought up her surviving children during her remaining eleven years of life. A small bequest from her Carter family enabled her to maintain the house in modest comfort. She suffered, however, from chronic health conditions herself. Her medical diagnosis, if any, is unknown, and her health challenges were primarily recorded as an additional obstacle to the young life of her fourth son Robert. Born in 1807, in his adolescent years Robert E. Lee assisted his mother to run the household. Although not poor, she was not able to face college tuition bills for Robert, who therefore sought higher education opportunities at the [[United States Military Academy]] at West Point. Young Lee did not hesitate to use his mother's Carter family kinship ties to co-sign his West Point application. During young Lee's West Point years (1825-1829), Anne Carter Lee's health further declined. She clung to life until the graduation of her son, and was given a place to live and be nursed at the home of an uncle, [[William Henry Fitzhugh]], the Fairfax County plantation of [[Ravensworth (plantation)|Ravensworth]]. Anne Hill Carter Lee died in Ravensworth on 26 July 1829. Her son Robert named one of his daughters, ''Anne Carter Lee'' (1839-1862), in honor of his mother.{{cite web|title=The Society of the Lees of Virginia|url=https://www.thesocietyoftheleesofva.org/|website=www.thesocietyoftheleesofva.org|publisher=The Society of the Lees of Virginia|accessdate=29 January 2018|language=en-gb}} ===Descendants=== Through her son Sydney, she was the grandmother of Confederate [[Major General]] [[Fitzhugh Lee]] (1835–1905), who later became [[Governor of Virginia]] (from 1886 to 1890), diplomat and writer; and served as Major General of [[United States Volunteers|U.S. Volunteers]] during the [[Spanish–American War]], as well as least four more grandsons who served in the Confederate States Army or Navy.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/robert-e-lee%E2%80%99s-%E2%80%9Cseverest-struggle%E2%80%9D|first=Elizabeth Brown|last=Pryor|title=Robert E. Lee's 'Severest Struggle'|publisher=American Heritage|year=2008}} Through her son Robert, she was the grandmother of seven, including [[George Washington Custis Lee]] (1832–1913), who served as Major General in the Confederate Army and [[aide-de-camp]] to President [[Jefferson Davis]], who died unmarried; Mary Custis Lee (1835–1918), who died unmarried; [[William Henry Fitzhugh Lee]] (1837–1891), who served as Major General in the Confederate Army who married twice; Anne Carter Lee (1839–1862), who died unmarried of [[typhoid fever]]; Eleanor Agnes Lee (1841–1873), who died unmarried of [[tuberculosis]]; [[Robert Edward Lee, Jr.]] (1843–1914), who served as Captain of the [[1st Rockbridge Artillery|Rockbridge Artillery]] and who married twice; and Mildred Childe Lee (1846–1905), who died unmarried.{{harvnb|Fellman|2000}} ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|30em}} '''Sources''' * {{Cite book|first=Michael|last=Fellman|title=The Making of Robert E. Lee|publisher=[[Random House]]|year=2000|isbn=0-679-45650-3|ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x7OOraQWi5wC}} ==External links== * {{Findagrave|20721812}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lee, Anne Hill Carter}} [[Category:1773 births]] [[Category:1829 deaths]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:Lee family of Virginia]] [[Category:People from Alexandria, Virginia]]

Business Acumen
Leadership Development
Assessment Centers
Sales Force Transformation
Innovation | area_served = Worldwide | homepage = {{Official website|http://www.bts.com/}} }} '''BTS Group AB''' ('''BTS''') is a global strategy implementation consulting firm founded in 1986. The company provides strategy alignment and execution consulting services and designs customized business simulations, digital technology, and assessments to develop business acumen, leadership, and sales capabilities.{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=BTSB:SS |title=BTS Group Ab-B Shares (BTSB:Stockholm) |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek |date= |accessdate=2014-08-30}} BTS has several practice areas - Strategy Execution, Business Acumen, Leadership Development, Sales Training, Innovation, Coaching and Assessments.{{cite web|url=http://www.bts.com/what-we-do |title=BTS Group AB (BTSb.ST) |publisher= TS |date= |accessdate=2015-09-09}} The company serves banking, biotech and pharmaceutical, consumer products, insurance, manufacturing, oil and gas, professional services, retail, technology, and telecommunications sectors.{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=BTSB:SS |title=BTS Group Ab-B Shares (BTSB:Stockholm) |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek |date= |accessdate=2014-09-04}} Headquartered in [[Stockholm, Sweden]], the firm has over 600 employees across 34 global offices. The company's client base is spread across 53 countries and includes 60 of the U.S. Fortune 100 and over 30 of the Global Fortune 100.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaqomxnordic.com/aktier/microsite?Instrument=SSE13288&name=BTS%20Group%20B |title=BTS B, BTS GROUP B, (SE0000805426) |publisher=NASDAQ OMX (Nordic) |accessdate=2014-08-30}} BTS customers include companies such as [[Accenture]], Aetna, [[Unilever]], [[AT&T]], Chevron, [[Coca-Cola]], [[Ericsson]], Google, GSK, [[Telstra]], HSBC, [[Hewlett-Packard]], Mondelez, Salesforce.com, Sodexo, [[Toyota]], and others.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/overview?symbol=BTSb.ST |title=BTS Group AB (BTSb.ST) |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2014-08-30}} BTS is a public company listed on the [[NASDAQ]]-[[OMX]] Stockholm trading under the symbol BTS B.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaqomxnordic.com/shares/microsite?Instrument=SSE13288 |title=NASDAQ OMX (Nordic) |publisher=NASDAQ |date= |accessdate=2014-08-19}} == Organizational History == [[File:Henrik-Ekelund.jpg|BTS CEO and founder, Henrik Ekelund|thumb|right|205px]]BTS was founded in 1986 by [[Henrik Ekelund]], current President and Chief Executive Officer, with the support of three investors from one of Scandinavia’s prominent strategic consulting firms. The firm focused on supporting clients’ efforts to implement strategy by focusing on the human capital part of the execution equation.{{cite web|title=Hög tid att utse|url=http://www.bts.com/docs/press/ekelund-degans-industri-article.pdf?sfvrsn=2|publisher=BTS Group}} In February 2005, BTS acquired Strategic Management Group, Inc. (SMG). The acquisition enabled the firm to create a broader base for future organic growth and deepen its expertise. In September 2006, BTS acquired The Real Learning Company (RLC) and Advantage Performance Group, Inc. (APG).{{cite web |title=BTS Group AB Has Completed the Acquisition of The Advantage Performance Group and The Real Learning Company |url=http://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/news/read?GUID=243657 |publisher=Financial Content |access-date=2014-08-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826113546/http://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/news/read?GUID=243657 |archive-date=2014-08-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The acquisitions consolidated a highly fragmented market and expanded the company's existing sales and leadership programs. In July 2013, BTS acquired Wizer A/S to expand the firm's digital capabilities and compliment its existing portfolio.{{cite web|title=BTS Group AB (BTSb.ST) |url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/overview?symbol=BTSb.ST | publisher=Reuters}} In October 2014, BTS acquired Fenestra Inc., a global provider of premier technology-enhanced assessment and leadership development centers and [[solution]]s.{{Cite web|title = BTS Group AB acquires all the businesses of Fenestra, Inc.|url = http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2014/10/17/674012/0/en/BTS-Group-AB-acquires-all-the-businesses-of-Fenestra-Inc.html|website = GlobeNewswire News Room|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} In March 2015, BTS acquired AVO Vision, a South African-based company focused on corporate learning and development as well as community-worksite education. The acquisition expanded the firm's global reach and expertise in the leadership development sphere as AVO Vision's core offerings focused on leadership, management, self-mastery, and sales execution skills.{{Cite web|title = BTS has Acquired a Leading South African Learning & Development Company|url = http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2015/03/26/718930/0/en/BTS-has-Acquired-a-Leading-South-African-Learning-Development-Company.html|website = globenewswire.com|accessdate = 2015-03-26}} In 2016, BTS Group acquired Cesim Italia Srl and Design Innovation Srl based in Milan, Italy to strengthen its Southern European position.{{Cite web|title = BTS buys two Italian companies|url = https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/BTSb.ST/key-developments/article/3400925|website = reuters.com|accessdate = 2016-07-06}} In September 2015, BTS launched a new brand, logo, tagline ("Strategy made personal") and website, designed in partnership with UK-based [http://saffron-consultants.com/ Saffron Brand Consultants].{{Cite web|title = Strategy made personal|url = http://www.bts.com/news-insights/strategy-execution-blog/strategy-execution/2015/09/15/bts-brand-has-evolved|website = www.bts.com|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} == Services == BTS supports executive management in the areas of strategy transformation, business and financial decision-making, key performance indicator alignment, merger integration, cross business-unit collaboration, innovation and customer understanding and relations.{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=BTSB:SS |title=BTS GROUP AB-B SHARES (BTSB:SS): Stock Quote & Company Profile |publisher=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date= |accessdate=2014-08-19}} Client engagement teams typically consist of a combination of industry experts, capability specialists and professionals with local market knowledge. The company helps organizations in the implementation of change and the improvement of profitability through the following practice areas: * Strategy Execution * [[Business Acumen]] * [[Leadership Development]] * Sales Force Transformation * Coaching *Assessment Centers *Innovation == Global Structure == * North America: [[New York City]], New York; [[Stamford, Connecticut]]; [[Chicago]], Illinois; [[Austin, Texas]]; [[Scottsdale, Arizona]]; [[Los Angeles]], California; [[San Francisco]], California; * Europe: [[Helsinki]], Finland; [[Stockholm]], Sweden; [[Munich]], Germany; [[Amsterdam]], Netherlands; [[Brussels]], Belgium; [[Paris]], France; [[London]], England; [[Bilbao, Spain]], [[Madrid]], Spain; [[Rome]], Italy * Middle East: [[Dubai]], United Arab Emirates * Asia: [[Bangalore]], India; [[Mumbai]], India; [[Bangkok]], Thailand; [[Shanghai]], China; [[Seoul]], South Korea; [[Singapore]]; [[Taipei]], Taiwan; [[Tokyo]], Japan * Central and South America: [[Mexico City]], Mexico; [[Sao Paulo]], Brazil * Australia: [[Sydney]], Australia; [[Melbourne]], Australia * Africa: [[Johannesburg]], South Africa == Awards, Honors & Publications == In 2017, BTS was named a Top 20 Leadership Training Company by [http://www.trainingindustry.com/ Training Industry].{{Cite web|url=http://www.trainingindustry.com/leadership/top-companies-listings/2017/2017-top-20-leadership-training-companies-list.aspx|title=2017 Top 20 Leadership Training Companies List {{!}} Training |url=http://www.trainingindustry.com/leadership/top-companies-listings/2013/2013-top-20-leadership-training-companies.aspx|publisher=Training Industry}} In 2016, BTS received two [http://www.brandonhall.com/excellenceawards/ Brandon Hall Awards] for client partnerships - a Gold with Intuit for the Best Unique or Innovative Leadership Development Program, and a Silver with MetLife for the Best Advance in Assessment Utilization to Guide Talent Decisions Category.{{Cite web|url=http://www.brandonhall.com/excellenceawards/past-winners.php|title=Past Winners|website=www.brandonhall.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-24}} BTS received a Silver 2013 Brandon Hall Group Excellence in Learning Award for their partnership with [[AT&T]] to create the AT&T Sales and Service Center Simulation.{{cite web|title=Winners of the 2013 Brandon Hall Group Excellence in Learning Awards |url=http://brandonhall.com/excellence-learning.php?year=2013|publisher=Brandon Hall Group}} BTS client [[Newell Rubbermaid]] was awarded Sales Training Program of the Year by [[Stevie Awards]] for their customized [[solution]].{{cite web|title=2011 Stevie Awards for Sales & Customer Service|url=http://www.stevieawards.com/pubs/sales/awards/426_2281_20877.cfm?fromMobileSite=1|publisher=Stevie Awards}} BTS Asia Pacific received a 2016 HR Vendors of the Year Award, hosted by Human Resources Magazine, in the Best Leadership Development Consultant Category.{{Cite news|url=http://www.humanresourcesonline.net/events/winners-photos-hr-vendors-year-2016-singapore/|title=Winners and photos: HR Vendors of the Year 2016, Singapore|date=2016-11-25|newspaper=Human Resources Online|access-date=2017-02-24|language=en-US}} ==Sponsorship== Since 2010, BTS USA has partnered with [[Rainforest Trust]] on sustainability campaigns to preserve threatened rainforests. In 2015, BTS sponsored the second round of the Rainforest Trust #SkiptoSave campaign supporting Rainforest Trust's 2020 Initiative designed to protect 20 million acres of rainforest by 2020.{{cite web|title=Consulting Firm Teams with Rainforest Trust to Save Tropical Forest|url=https://www.rainforesttrust.org/news/bts-usa-saves-colombian-rainforest/|publisher=Rainforest Trust}} In partnership with the Sparkassesntiftung fur international Kooperation (Savings Banks Foundation for International Cooperation), BTS has created a business simulation program to teach business and financial acumen in developing nations.{{cite web|title=Annual Report 2009|url=http://www.sparkassenstiftung.de/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/Jahresberichte/JB_2009_E.pdf/|publisher=Finanzgruppe Sparkassenstiftung fur international Kooperation}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As of June 2015, such programs had been held for more than 10,000 participants in 12 countries. ==Management== {| class="wikitable" |- ! [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1986-0226-333, Bonn, Besuch Volkskammer-Delegation, Sindermann cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Berthold Beitz (1986)]]
'''Berthold Beitz''' (26 September 1913 – 30 July 2013) was a German industrialist. He was the head of the [[ThyssenKrupp|Krupp]] steel conglomerate beginning in the 1950s. He was credited with helping to lead the re-industrialization of the [[Ruhr Valley]] and rebuilding [[Germany]] into an industrial power. He gained acclaim for saving some 250 [[Jew]]ish workers during [[World War II]] by declaring them to be essential workers at an oil facility in [[Poland]]. In 1973, for saving Jews, he received the [[Righteous Among the Nations]] title awarded by the [[Israel]]i [[Yad Vashem]], the highest honor given to a non-Jew.
==Early years== Beitz was born in 1913 in [[Bentzin|Zemmin]], [[Hither Pomerania]]. He began his career as a banker at the "Pommersche Bank" in [[Stralsund]] and started to work for [[Shell Oil Company]] in [[Hamburg]] in 1938.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=Berthold Beitz, German Steel Industrialist Who Saved Jews, Dies at 99|first= Melissa |last= Eddy|date=August 1, 2013 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/02/business/berthold-beitz-german-steel-industrialist-who-saved-jews-dies-at-99.html?ref=obituaries}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Beitz, Eine deutsche Geschichte |language=de |trans-title=Beitz, A German History |first= Norbert F. |last= Pötzl |publisher=Heyne |date=2011 | accessdate= August 3, 2013 |oclc=948635931 |isbn=9783641068110 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=6oIpJpM31T8C&pg=PT33}}</ref>
==World War II== Beitz remained in the employ of Shell Oil when World War II began in 1939. Following Germany's invasion and occupation of [[Boryslav|Borysław]] in July 1941, Beitz was assigned to supervise the Carpathian Oil Company operating the [[Boryslav|Borysław]] oil fields in what is now [[Ukraine]]. Given the importance of the oil fields to the German war effort, Beitz was able to designate workers as essential to the war effort.<ref name=YV>{{cite web|title=Berthold and Elsa Beitz|publisher=Yad Vashem|accessdate=August 2, 2013|url=http://www.yad-vashem.org.il/yv/en/righteous/stories/beitz.asp}}</ref> The Borysław area had a large Jewish population, with many Jews holding positions as chemical engineers, laboratory assistants, mechanics, and laborers in the area's oil industry.<ref name=YV/>
After witnessing the "Invaliden-Aktion" in August 1942, an [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]-led evacuation of a Jewish orphanage in Borysław, Beitz became determined to act to save local Jews. Having a position of importance, Beitz received advance word of Nazi actions against local Jews and provided warning to the Jewish community. He also had the opportunity to select suitable workers from Jews who were being held at transfer points for deportation to concentration camps. In August 1942, he "extricated 250 Jewish men and women from the transport train to the [[Belzec extermination camp]] by claiming them as 'professional workers.'"<ref name=YV/><ref name=DW>{{cite news |title= Berthold Beitz, ThyssenKrupp patriarch who saved wartime Jews, dies aged 99| publisher= Deutsche Welle| date=31 July 2013|url=http://www.dw.de/berthold-beitz-thyssenkrupp-patriarch-who-saved-wartime-jews-dies-aged-99/a-16990234}}</ref> Beitz recalled, "I should have employed qualified personnel. Instead, I chose tailors, hairdressers and Talmudic scholars and gave them all cards as vital 'petroleum technicians.'"<ref name=Aus/>
Together with his wife Else, Beitz also hid Jews in his home.<ref name=YV/><ref name=JWN/><ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=German magnate Berthold Beitz who saved Jews in WWII dies|publisher=BBC|date=July 31, 2013|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-23522382}}</ref> He also issued and signed fake work permits to save other Jews from the death camps.<ref name=JWN>{{cite news|title=Berthold Beitz, savior of hundreds of Jews during the Holocaust, dies at 99|newspaper=Jewish World News|date=August 1, 2013|url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/jewish-world-news/.premium-1.539040}}</ref> In 1943, Beitz's efforts were nearly exposed after two Jewish girls were arrested on a train to [[Hungary]] with forged "Aryan" permits signed by Beitz. Beitz survived despite a Gestapo investigation into the incident, but he was drafted into the German army in March 1944.<ref name=YV/> In total, Beitz has been credited with saving the lives of 800 Jews.<ref name=Aus>{{cite web|title=Berthold Beitz|publisher=Auschwitz.com|accessdate=August 2, 2013|url=http://auschwitz.dk/rescuers/id16.htm}}</ref>
Beitz later explained his motivation: "I saw how people were shot, how they were lined up in the night. My motives were not political; they were purely humane, moral motives."<ref name=NYT/> In another interview, he explained: "It wasn't anti-Fascism, nor was it resistance. We saw from dawn to dusk, as close as could be, what was happening to Boryslav's Jews. When you see a mother holding her children being shot, while you yourself have children, your reaction has to be completely different."<ref name=JWN/>
For his efforts in saving Jewish workers, Beitz received Poland's highest civilian honor.<ref name=NYT/> In 1973, he was also honored by [[Yad Vashem]], the Israeli Holocaust memorial, as a "Righteous Among the Nations", the organization's highest honor for non-Jews who saved Jews from the Holocaust.<ref name=DW/> According to Yad Vashem, "The Jews that he rescued from deportation included many unqualified workers, often in poor physical condition, who could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be described as 'professionals' or indispensable to the oil industry."<ref name=YV/>
==Post-war business career== After the war, Beitz became the head of Iduna, an insurance company. His innovative business methods and compensation brought him attention. In 1953, [[Alfried Krupp]] hired him to become chairman of the [[Friedrich Krupp AG|Krupp]] steel corporation. He remained with the company for 60 years and helped build it into a publicly traded conglomerate, merging the company in the 1990s to form [[ThyssenKrupp]]. Beitz has also been credited with helping to lead the re-industrialization of the [[Ruhr Valley]] where Krupp's operations were based.<ref name=NYT/>
After Alfried Krupp's death in 1967, Beitz served as executor and persuaded the Krupp heirs to establish a charitable foundation known as the [[Alfried Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach Foundation]]. The foundation still owns 25% of ThyssenKrupp.<ref name=NYT/> Beitz remained active in the foundation and led its effort to fund the creation of the [[Museum Folkwang]] in [[Essen]].<ref name=NYT/>
From 1972 to 1988, Beitz was a member of the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) and an honorary member until his death. From 1984 to 1988, he was an IOC vice president and executive board member.<ref>{{cite web|title=Death of Berthold Beitz, IOC Honorary Member|publisher=Olympic.org |date=July 31, 2013|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/death-of-berthold-beitz-ioc-honorary-member/206954}}</ref>
In 2000, he received the Leo-Baeck Award, the highest honor bestowed by the [[Central Council of Jews in Germany]].<ref name=BBC/><ref>{{cite news|title=Berthold Beitz: Industrialist who saved hundreds of Jews from the Nazis|newspaper=The Independent|date=August 1, 2013|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/berthold-beitz-industrialist-who-saved-hundreds-of-jews-from-the-nazis-8742688.html}}</ref>
In July 2013, Beitz died at age 99 at his holiday home on the island of [[Sylt]] off the northern coast of Germany.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thyssen-Krupp-Chef Hiesinger: "Verneige mich" vor Patriarch Beitz|newspaper=Spiegel|date=August 2, 2013|url=http://www.spiegel.de/thema/berthold_beitz/}}</ref> He is survived by his wife Else and three daughters.<ref name=NYT/> Following Beitz's death, [[Ronald Lauder]], president of the [[World Jewish Congress]], called Beitz "one of the great Germans of the past century."<ref name=DW/>

{{Infobox theatre |name = Boyd's Theater and Opera House |image = |caption = |address = 1621 Harney Street |city = [[Omaha, Nebraska|Omaha]], [[Nebraska]] |country = [[United States]] |coordinates = {{coord|41.25655|-95.93747|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |designation = |architect = |owner = James E. Boyd, later Burgess-Nash Co. |capacity = 2,000 |type = Theater and Opera House |opened = {{Start date|1891|09|3}} |yearsactive = 1891–1920 |rebuilt = |closed = February 2, 1920 |othernames = |production = |currentuse = }} '''Boyd's Theater and Opera House''' was a [[theatre|theater]] and [[opera house]] at 1621 Harney Street in [[Downtown Omaha]], [[Nebraska]].<ref name="Building For The Ages">{{cite book|last=Jeffrey S. Spencer [researcher and writer]|first=Kristine Gerber [project director]|title=Building for the ages : Omaha's architectural landmarks|year=2003|publisher=Omaha Books|location=Omaha, Neb.|isbn=0-9745410-1-X|page=20|edition=1st}}</ref> It was demolished in 1920 and the property redeveloped for the then owner's department store business.<ref name="Building For The Ages" />
== History ==
The first Boyd's Opera House in Omaha was built in 1881 at 15th and Farnam Streets by [[James E. Boyd (politician)|James E. Boyd]].<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> In addition to serving as Nebraska's governor and Omaha's mayor, Boyd was a successful railroad and real estate developer.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> One of the first celebrities to appear at the original Boyd's was [[Oscar Wilde]] in 1882.<ref name="Oscar Wilde ay Boyd's">{{cite web|title=Oscar Wilde lectures at Boyd's in Omaha|url=http://oscarwildeinamerica.org/lectures-1882/march/0321-omaha.html}}</ref> After the original Boyd Opera House burned twelve years later, Boyd built his new 2,000 seat theater and opera house at 17th and Harney Streets.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /><ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />
The new five story theater was constructed on an iron framework with a pressed red brick exterior.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> There was retail space on the street level, and office space within the interior.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> The total cost of construction and furnishings was $250,000.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> The Boyd Theater's stage was 78 feet wide, 40 feet deep and 60 feet high.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater">{{cite news|last=Fanders|first=R. H.|title=When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater|newspaper=The Omaha World-Herald Newspaper, Omaha, Douglas County, NE, USA|date=October 6, 1963|pages=126–127}}</ref> The curtain drops were 26 feet by 46 feet.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> The [[proscenium]] was modeled after an ornate arch in the [[Taj Mahal]].<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> The theater was decorated in tones of sage green and soft tones of olive to compliment the electric lighting throughout.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />
There were 17 full sets of scenery when the theater opened on September 3, 1891.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> The first play presented on the house's stage was ''Alabama'', with Thomas F. Boyd as the theater's manager.<ref name="Raze Boyd Theater Soon For New Store">{{cite news|title=Raze Boyd Theater Soon For New Store|newspaper=The Omaha World-Herald Newspaper, Omaha, Douglas County, NE, USA|date=June 10, 1919|page=4}}</ref> One particularly elaborate production of ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'' required the theater to accommodate 10 train cars of [[armour]], 200 trunks of costumes, 167 professional actors and 21 full sets.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> Once local actors were added to the production, the cast ultimately rose to 300.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> The Boyd Theater was capable of handling even productions of this size.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />
Some of the most prominent actors of the time appeared on the Boyd Theater's stage. English [[Shakespearean]] actors [[Sir Henry Irving]] and [[Dame Ellen Terry]] appeared twice in Omaha.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> The first time was April 20 and 21, 1900 with the productions of ''[[Merchant of Venice]]'', ''Nance Oldfield'' and ''[[The Bells (play)|The Bells]]''. Their second appearances occurred on December 31, 1901 and January 1, 1902.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> Other toasted performers to grace Boyd Theater's stage included: [[Otis Skinner]], [[E. H. Sothern]], [[John Drew (actor)|John Drew]], [[Walker Whiteside]], [[Robert B. Mantell]] [[Joseph Jefferson]], [[Mrs. Leslie Carter|Leslie Carter]], [[Julia Marlowe]], [[Ethel Barrymore]] and [[Maude Adams]].<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />
A man bled to death in the wings of the Boyd Theater during one performance, with no one in the audience the wiser.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> A song and dance man, Jim Mulligan, died after being stabbed by Arthur Sprague, a stage manager, after making an offensive comment about Mrs. Sprague.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />
[[File:Félix Nadar - Sarah Bernhardt in La Tosca 1887.jpg|thumb|Sarah Bernhardt in ''La Tosca'', circa 1887]] In 1905, [[Sarah Bernhardt]] appeared on the Boyd Theater stage in ''[[La Tosca]]''.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> Bernhardt traveled with her own custom railway car.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> Also traveling with her on the train was her own carriage, a team of black horses, and a French [[coachman]] and [[hostler]].<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> The entire city knew when Bernhardt was in town.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />
Omaha-born [[pianist]] Frances Nash, who would later marry [[Edwin "Pa" Watson|Edwin Watson]], friend and senior advisor to President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], often performed at Boyd's Theater.<ref name="Nash-Hamlin Recital">{{cite web|title=Nash-Hamlin Recital|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99021999/1916-02-01/ed-1/seq-5/#date1=1836&index=1&rows=20&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&words=Boyd+Frances+Nash+theater&proxdistance=5&date2=1922&ortext=&proxtext=boyd%27s+theater+frances+nash&phrasetext=&andtext=&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|publisher=The Omaha Bee News Newspaper, Omaha, Douglas County, NE, USA|accessdate=13 March 2014|page=5|date=February 1, 1916}}</ref><ref name="Gives Over Life of Ease for Art She Loves">{{cite web|title=Gives Over Life of Ease for Art She Loves|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99021999/1916-01-23/ed-1/seq-13/#date1=1836&index=1&rows=20&words=Frances+Nash&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1922&proxtext=frances+nash&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|publisher=The Omaha Sunday Bee News Newspaper, Omaha, Douglas County, NE, USA|accessdate=14 March 2014|page=1|date=January 23, 1916}}</ref>
The man primarily responsible for the quality and the variety of the shows appearing on the Boyd Theater's stage was William J. Burgess.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> Burgess had been involved in theaters since the age of 12.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> He initially came to Omaha to manage the Grand Opera House and later managed the original Boyd Theater.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> When the [[Creighton Orpheum Theater]] opened, he served as its manager for two years.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> Once that theater joined the [[Orpheum Circuit]], he took over the management of the second Boyd Theater and set about making it the premier live theater venue in Omaha.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> He introduced the first mail-order tickets in town and strived to book the premier acts. He even opened an acting school for fledging dramatists.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> But even Burgess's efforts could not sway the audiences changing tastes towards [[film|motion pictures]] and the rising costs of mounting a live stage production.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />
In 1914, Boyd's Theater was sold to the Burgess-Nash Company for $231,000.<ref name="Boyd theater Building Is Sold">{{cite web|title=Boyd Theater Building Is Sold|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99021999/1914-05-17/ed-1/seq-36/#date1=1836&index=17&date2=1922&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&words=Boyd+theater+Theater&proxdistance=5&state=Nebraska&rows=20&ortext=&proxtext=boyd%27s+theater&phrasetext=&andtext=&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|publisher=The Omaha Sunday Bee Newspaper, Omaha, Douglas County, NE, USA|accessdate=13 March 2014|page=PART THREE, Page 8-C, Image 36|date=May 17, 1914}}</ref> Initially they continued to manage it as a theater, but as the competition from [[sound film|talking movies]] increased, the company eventually closed the theater.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> The last performance in the theater was on February 2, 1920.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" /> It was demolished in 1920 and the property redeveloped for their department store business.<ref name="Building For The Ages" /> Currently, the property houses the [[Omaha Public Power District|Omaha Public Power District's]] downtown office.<ref name="When Omaha Had Its Golden Age of Theater" />

{{Infobox person | name = Brian Duperreault | image = Brian Duperreault.jpg | caption = Brian Duperreault | birth_place = [[Hamilton, Bermuda]] | nationality = American and Bermudian | education = [[B.S.]] [[Mathematics]] | alma_mater = [[Saint Joseph's University]] | occupation = President and CEO of [http://www.aig.com American International Group (AIG)] | years_active = 2017–present }}
'''Brian Duperreault''' is President and Chief Executive Officer of [[American International Group]] (AIG), succeeding [[Peter_Hancock_(CEO)|Peter Hancock]] in May 2017.
Duperreault's career spans 40 years. He was President and Chief Executive Officer of [[Marsh & McLennan Companies]] from 2008 to 2012. Before joining Marsh, he served for four years as non-executive Chairman of [[ACE Limited]], a global insurance and reinsurance company, CEO of ACE Limited from October 1994 through May 2004, and as the Company's President from October 1994 through November 1999.
Prior to joining ACE, Duperreault served in various senior executive positions with AIG and its affiliates from 1973 to 1994.
Duperreault is Chairman of Attune, a data-enabled company established by Hamilton Insurance Group, AIG and [[Two Sigma Investments|Two Sigma]]. He is the Chairman Emeritus of Blue Marble Microinsurance and former Chairman of the Board of Overseers of the School of Risk Management of [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John’s University, New York]].
Duperreault is a member of the boards of the International Insurance Society, [[IESE Business School]], [[Insurance Information Institute]], Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS), Johnson Controls, and Saint Joseph’s University, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
He is credited by the [[Insurance Hall of Fame]] with helping to transform Bermuda from an island nation with a small, reinsurance-focused market into a global insurance centre.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brian Duperreault|url=http://www.insurancehalloffame.org/laureateprofile.php?laureate=147|website=Insurance Hall of Fame}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bernews.com/bermuda-profiles/brian-duperreault/|website=Bernews}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis Johnson|first1=Wendy|title=Faith is my inspiration, says Duperreault on retirement from Marsh|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130116/BUSINESS04/701169964|accessdate=Jan 16, 2013|publisher=The Royal Gazette}}</ref> He currently resides in Bermuda.
In March 2013, Duperreault was asked by Bermuda's Finance Minister, the Hon. E.T. Richards,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oba.bm/index.php/latestnews/643-sage-commission-appointed/|website=One Bermuda Alliance}}</ref> to chair the Spending and Government Efficiency (SAGE) Commission.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130301/NEWS/702289910/|website=Royal Gazette}}</ref> The Commission's primary objective was to make government more efficient, cost-effective, transparent and user-friendly. The SAGE Commission submitted a final report with recommendations on October 31, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.bm/uploadedFiles/Content/Home/SAGE%20Commission%20Final%20Report.pdf/|website=Parliament.bm}}</ref>
==Early life==
Born in Bermuda, he left with his mother for Trenton, New Jersey when he was five months old.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bernews.com/bermuda-profiles/brian-duperreault/|website=Bernews}}</ref> He attended [[Saint Joseph's University]] in [[Philadelphia]] where he received a [[B.S.]] [[Mathematics|in Mathematics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=203030&ticker=MMC|website=Bloomberg}}</ref>
==Career==
After receiving his degree Duperreault served in the [[US Army|United States Army]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Treaster|first1=Joseph|title=An Insurer Goes Against the Odds; Ace Bucks the Trend and Expands in Commercial Coverage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/26/business/insurer-goes-against-odds-ace-bucks-trend-expands-commercial-coverage.html?pagewanted=all|issue=January 26, 1999}}</ref> He considered becoming a mathematics professor, but newly married, he decided he wanted a better income than an academic life could provide.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Treaster|first1=Joseoph|title=An Insurer Goes Against the Odds; Ace Bucks the Trend and Expands in Commercial Coverage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/26/business/insurer-goes-against-odds-ace-bucks-trend-expands-commercial-coverage.html?pagewanted=all|publisher=New York Times|date=January 26, 1999}}</ref> After he was discharged, he researched job ideas at a library, where he learned about the [[actuary]] profession.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Treaster|first1=Joseph|title=An Insurer Goes Against the Odds; Ace Bucks the Trend and Expands in Commercial Coverage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/26/business/insurer-goes-against-odds-ace-bucks-trend-expands-commercial-coverage.html?pagewanted=all|issue=January 26, 1999}}</ref> In 1973, he started with [[American International Group|AIG]], where he held many positions, eventually heading the Company's operations in Japan and South Korea, and ultimately leading nearly all its international business.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Treaster|first1=Joseph|title=An Insurer Goes Against the Odds; Ace Bucks the Trend and Expands in Commercial Coverage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/26/business/insurer-goes-against-odds-ace-bucks-trend-expands-commercial-coverage.html?pagewanted=all|issue=January 26, 1999}}</ref> Duperreault became a credentialed actuary with the [[Casualty Actuarial Society]] in 1975.<ref>{{cite news|title=CAS Member Named CEO of AIG|url=http://www.casact.org/press/index.cfm?fa=viewArticle&articleID=3668|issue=May 15, 2017}}</ref>
===Hamilton Insurance Group===
In December 2013, Duperreault came out of retirement a second time to establish Hamilton Insurance Group, a Bermuda-based holding company, with principals of Two Sigma, a technology company,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=203030&ticker=MMC|website=Bloomberg}}</ref> The company goal was to use a variety of forms of technology, including artificial intelligence, machine learning and distributed computing, to improve underwriting and investment strategies.<ref>{{cite news|title=Back for a reason: interview with Brian Duperreault|url=http://www.intelligentinsurer.com/article/back-for-a-reason-interview-with-brian-duperreault|accessdate=2014-11-27|publisher=Intelligent Insurer}}</ref>
===Return to AIG===
In May 2017, AIG named Duperreault as its new President and Chief Executive Officer, replacing [[Peter Hancock (businessman)|Peter Hancock]]. At the same time AIG announced that it would acquire Hamilton Insurance Group's US platform and partner with Hamilton and Two Sigma.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brian Duperreault|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/aig-names-brian-duperreault-as-its-ceo-2017-5}}</ref><ref>http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2017/05/15/aig-names-brian-duperreault-as-ceo-4th-update.html</ref>
==Personal life==
Duperreault and his wife Nancy have three sons: Daniel, David and Christopher. He credits his career success to his Jesuit education at [[Saint Joseph’s University]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis Johnson|first1=Wendy|title=Faith is my inspiration, says Duperreault on retirement from Marsh|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130116/BUSINESS04/701169964|accessdate=Jan 16, 2013|publisher=The Royal Gazette}}</ref> A devout [[Catholic]], he said of his faith, "It’s everything. It’s the essence of who I am. I try to pray for guidance all the time. It’s the best counsel you can seek."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis Johnson|first1=Wendy|title=Faith is my inspiration, says Duperreault on retirement from Marsh|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130116/BUSINESS04/701169964|accessdate=Jan 16, 2013|publisher=The Royal Gazette}}</ref> Duperreault claims the impact of his faith was most apparent when he was offered the opportunity to rehabilitate [[Marsh & McLennan]], which had been suffering organizational and financial woes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis Johnson|first1=Wendy|title=Faith is my inspiration, says Duperreault on retirement from Marsh|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130116/BUSINESS04/701169964|accessdate=Jan 16, 2013|publisher=The Royal Gazette}}</ref>
==Philanthropy==
Duperreault donated $10 million to his alma mater [[Saint Joseph’s University]], the largest individual gift in the history of the university.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bernews.com/bermuda-profiles/brian-duperreault/|website=Bernews}}</ref> He also worked on charitable matters in China with former US President Jimmy Carter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bernews.com/bermuda-profiles/brian-duperreault/|website=Bernews}}</ref> Duperreault developed Bermuda’s charitable sector, chairing the Council Partners Charitable Trust, The Centre on Philanthropy, the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS), and establishing The Duperreault Fellowship, an annual scholarship for professionals to enhance their credentials in combating substance abuse.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis Johnson|first1=Wendy|title=Faith is my inspiration, says Duperreault on retirement from Marsh|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130116/BUSINESS04/701169964|accessdate=Jan 16, 2013|publisher=The Royal Gazette}}</ref>
==Awards and affiliations==
* Member of Board of the International Insurance Society * Member of the Board of the IESE Business School * Member of the Board of the Insurance Information Institute * Member of the Board of the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS) * Chairman of the Board of Directors of Attune * Member of the American Academy of Actuaries * Associate of the Casualty Actuarial Society * Chairman of the Board of Blue Marble Microinsurance * Former member of the Association of The Metropolitan Opera * Past Chairman of the Board of Overseers of The School of Risk Management, Insurance and Actuarial Science of St. John’s University
==Honors and recognition==
* Insurance Hall of Fame—inducted in year 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insurancehalloffame.org/laureateprofile.php?laureate=147|title=Brian Duperreault|website=Insurance Hall of Fame}}</ref> * Honorary Doctorate from Saint Joseph's University - 2007 * Bermuda Insurance Institute - 2006 Lifetime Achievement Award * Honorary Doctorate of Commercial Science Degree from St. John's University - 2006 * School of Risk Management, St. John's University - 2004 Insurance Leader of the Year
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Cash Flow From Australia | image = Cashflowlogo.jpg | caption = The caption of ''Cash Flow'' when it was broadcast from CNBC Asia's Australian studios in Sydney. | genre = business [[news program]] | camera = | picture_format = | audio_format = | runtime = 120 minutes | creator = | developer = | producer = | executive_producer = | presenter = Maura Fogarty (2007–2010)
[[Amanda Drury]] (2007–2010)
Oriel Morrison (2010–2014)
[[Bernard Lo]] (2010–2014) | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = Australia | location = Singapore (2007–2010)
Sydney, Australia (2010–2014) | language = English | network = [[CNBC Asia]] | first_aired = {{start date|df=yes|2007|03|26}} (as ''CNBC's Cash Flow'') | last_aired = {{end date|df=yes|2014|03|28}} | num_seasons = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | preceded_by = CNBC Asia:
'''''[[Asia Market Watch]]''''' | followed_by = ''[[Street Signs (TV series)|Street Signs]]'' | related = | website = https://web.archive.org/web/20070427204316/http://www.cnbc.com/id/17501787/site/14081545/ }} '''''Cash Flow''''' (formerly '''''CNBC's Cash Flow '''''and '''''Cash Flow From Australia''''') was a television business news program on [[CNBC Asia]]. It is produced by CNBC Asia from Singapore by a team of journalists and aired each weekday at 10:00 am Singapore/Hong Kong/[[Taiwan]] time. It was broadcast live from [[CNBC Asia]]'s studio in Sydney and presented by Oriel Morrison and at Hong Kong's studio presented by [[Bernard Lo]] for the first hour. It was originally presented by Maura Fogarty for the first hour and Amanda Drury for the second hour and was broadcast live from Singapore. ''Cash Flow'' was seen in the United States on the [[CNBC World]] channel every Sunday through Thursday at 10:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Time]] (9:00 pm ET without [[Daylight Saving Time]]) and on [[CNBC Europe]] at 3:00 [[UTC]] ==Program Facts== *''Cash Flow'', which debuted on 26 March 2007 as ''CNBC's Cash Flow'', replaced ''[[Asia Market Watch]]'' (also anchored by Amanda Drury), a mid-morning Asian market program that followed ongoing stock market trading in Asia. The show was given a clear mandate—to provide actionable strategies on investments and help viewers make sense of the morning's news flow. This was part of CNBC Asia's significant programming revamp that resulted in the cancellation of ''Asia Market Watch'', and the debut of ''[[Squawk Australia]]'', which moved ''[[Asia Squawk Box]]'' (which Drury co-anchored with Martin Soong) down an hour. *The second hour of ''Cash Flow'' is also seen in the Philippines over [[ABS-CBN News Channel|ANC]]. ANC, however has the option of pre-empting the simulcast in case of breaking news or live events such as Senate/House hearings and Christmas/Year End programs of ANC's shows. * It features stock reports from CNBC reporters around the Asia Pacific region including [[Emily Chan]] (Hong Kong), [[Kaori Enjoji]] (Tokyo), [[Cheng Lei]] (Shanghai) and [[Tanvir Gill]] of [[CNBC-TV18]] ([[Mumbai]]). Plus [[Sri Jegarajah]] and [[Adam Bakhtiar]] at [[CNBC Asia]]'s Singapore studios. *''Cash Flow'' started broadcasting from the news room set in July 2009. The move out of the virtual set means that all CNBC Asia programs now originate from a hard set. This program moved to Sydney in 2010, after Maura Fogarty departed from the network. *''Trading Matters'', once a standalone programme on the network wrapping-up the trading day in Australia was folded to become a segment on ''Cash Flow'' at around 11.40 HK/SIN time. It now features live reports from the [[Australian Stock Exchange]] and analysis of stories from down under. *On 14 June 2010, ''CNBC's Cash Flow'' was renamed ''Cash Flow From Australia'' to reflect the program's change of location. [[Oriel Morrison]] became the sole anchor of the program, replacing original anchors Amanda Drury and Maura Fogarty. * On 2 January 2013, ''Cash Flow From Australia ''was shortened to ''Cash Flow, ''dropping the second half of the program's name (''From Australia'') from the title. ==See also== *''[[Asia Market Watch]]'' (the program ''Cash Flow'' replaced) *''[[The Call (CNBC)|The Call]]'' (a late-morning CNBC US program that follows ongoing stock market trading in the US) ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070427204316/http://www.cnbc.com/id/17501787/site/14081545/ ''Cash Flow'' Official Website] {{CNBC World Business Day}} {{CNBC Europe Business Day}} {{CNBC Asia Business Day}} [[Category:2000s Australian television series]] [[Category:2010s Australian television series]] [[Category:2007 Australian television series debuts]] [[Category:2014 Australian television series endings]] [[Category:Business-related television series]] [[Category:CNBC World programs]] [[Category:CNBC Europe programmes]] [[Category:CNBC Asia programs]] [[Category:Television news programmes]]

{{Infobox person |name = Chad Troutwine |image = Chad Troutwine.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = May 23, 1968 |birth_place = Kansas City, Missouri |education = {{plainlist| *[[Fort Osage High School]] *[[Arizona State University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])}} *[[University of Missouri]] {{small|([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]])}} *[[Yale University]] {{small|([[Master of Business Administration|M.B.A.]])}} *[[Harvard University]] {{small|([[Master of Public Administration|M.P.A.]])}}}} |occupation = {{plainlist| *CEO of [[Veritas Prep]] *Co-Founder of Codesmith *Co-Founder of Torn Label Brewing Co. *Co-Founder of Spectrum Station Early Childhood Education *Co-Founder of Freakonomics Media}} |nationality = |spouse = {{marriage|Sacha Radford|2015}} }} '''Chad Troutwine''' (born May 23, 1968) is an American [[Independent film]] producer and Co-Founder and [[CEO]] of [[Veritas Prep]]. ==Early life and education== As a child, Troutwine's parents encouraged his entrepreneurial spirit and placed a high value on education. Troutwine earned a perfect score on the [[Stanford Achievement Test]], and graduated high school at the age of sixteen. Troutwine earned his BA from [[Arizona State University]] at nineteen, and went on to earn a JD from the [[University of Missouri]], graduating with honors, an [[MBA]] from the [[Yale School of Management]], and received a master's degree in Public Administration from the [[Harvard Kennedy School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.veritasprep.com/meet-the-team/|title=Meet the Team - Veritas Prep|first=|last=VeritasPrep|website=www.veritasprep.com}} ==Entrepreneurship== While at Yale, Troutwine and [[Markus Moberg]], launched [[Veritas Prep]], a GMAT preparation and MBA admissions consulting company.{{cite web |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/university-news/2009/04/23/qa-som-grads-find-success-in-test-prep/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120918224624/http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/university-news/2009/04/23/qa-som-grads-find-success-in-test-prep/ |archivedate=2012-09-18 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailypennsylvanian.com/node/53396|title=A Devilish time on tap in NCAAs|first=Jennifer|last=Scuteri|publisher=}} Veritas Prep has become the world's largest privately owned test preparation and admissions consulting company, and now prepares students for the [[SAT]], [[ACT (test)|ACT]], and [[GRE]].{{cite web|url=http://www.veritasprep.com/blog/|title=GMAT Prep - SAT Prep - Admissions Consulting - Veritas Prep Blog|website=www.veritasprep.com}} In recognition of his entrepreneurial endeavors, [[Forbes magazine]] named Troutwine their 2002 Forbes Future Capitalist of the Year.{{cite web |url=http://www.ndeclub.org/article/id:3 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727114349/http://www.ndeclub.org/article/id%3A3 |archivedate=2011-07-27 |df= }} Seven years later, [[Entrepreneur magazine]] featured Troutwine and Moberg as Top 20 Trailblazers and Trendsetters for 2009.{{Cite web |url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/goforward/forwardthinkers/slideshow/index.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-04-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110050108/http://www.entrepreneur.com/goforward/forwardthinkers/slideshow/index.html |archive-date=2010-01-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }} After Troutwine co-founded Freakonomics Media, the Freakonomics franchise grew from its original book to a movie, radio show, more books, and a multimedia website.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2011/01/14/freakonomics-leaving-ny-times-to-start-own-venture/|title=Freakonomics Leaving NY Times to Start Own Venture|first=Jeff|last=Bercovici|publisher=}} In 2014, Troutwine co-founded Torn Label Brewing Company in Kansas City, MO.{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/business/biz-columns-blogs/cityscape/article343803/New-brewery-opening-in-the-Crossroads.html|title=New brewery opening in the Crossroads|publisher=}} A year later, in 2015, Troutwine co-founded the Los Angeles computer coding academy, Codesmith.{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/codesmith-launches-elite-coding-academy-hq-in-la-addressing-tech-talent-gap-2015-05-07|title=Codesmith Launches Elite Coding Academy HQ in LA Addressing Tech Talent Gap|publisher=}} In 2016, Codesmith announced it had received over $1 million in funding.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/losangeles/news/2016/10/18/codesmith-feels-like-a-million-bucks-after-funding.html |title=Codesmith feels like a million bucks after funding round |last=Ellingson |first=Annlee |date=October 18, 2016 |website=www.bizjournals.com}} As of July 2016, Codesmith alumni had a 96% hiring rate at an average salary of $103,000.{{cite web|url=http://tech.co/coding-bootcamp-96-percent-hiring-rate-2016-07|title=LA Coding Bootcamp Codesmith Boasts 96% Hiring Rate|date=27 July 2016|publisher=}} Troutwine is an investor and member of the Board of Directors of the [[crowdfunding]] and film distribution platform, [[Seed&Spark]].{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/seed-spark-taps-chicken-eggs-julie-parker-benello-and-veritas-preps-chad-troutwine-to-join-board-of-directors-20140808|title=Seed&Spark Taps Chicken & Egg’s Julie Parker Benello and Veritas Prep’s Chad Troutwine to Join Board of Directors|first=Shipra Harbola|last=Gupta|date=9 August 2014|publisher=}} Troutwine is also an advisor to [[SoloPro]], a real estate startup venture founded by former [[US Army Special Forces]] officer and [[Duke University]] professor [[Tommy Sowers]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.solopro.com/press-releases/chad-troutwine-solo-advisor |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-07-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702112653/https://www.solopro.com/press-releases/chad-troutwine-solo-advisor |archive-date=2015-07-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ===Henry Crown Fellow, the Aspen Institute=== In 2013, the [[Aspen Institute]] named Troutwine a member of the Henry Crown Fellowship.{{cite web|url=http://www.aspeninstitute.org/leadership-programs/henry-crown-fellowship-program/lists-fellows/2013-fellows|title=Henry Crown Fellowship - The Aspen Institute|publisher=}} ==Film and Arts== In January 2001, Troutwine established Chad Troutwine Films. His films have premiered at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] and the [[Cannes Film Festival]] and featured award-winning actors (including [[James Woods]], [[Nick Nolte]], [[Vince Vaughn]], [[Miranda Richardson]], [[Steve Buscemi]], [[Bob Hoskins]], and [[Natalie Portman]]), and directors ([[Joel and Ethan Coen]], [[Alex Gibney]], [[Morgan Spurlock]], [[Gus Van Sant]], [[Alfonso Cuaron]], [[Seth Gordon]], and [[Alexander Payne]]).[http://mba.yale.edu/alumni/alumni_leaders/troutwinec.shtml Yale School of Management - Alumni Leaders - Chad Troutwine '02] In 2008, Troutwine joined Dan O'Meara and Chris Romano at the Green Film Company, a New York-based production company.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/05/business/media/05freak.html|title=‘Freakonomics’ May Find Hidden Side of Documentary: Profit|first=Michael|last=Cieply|publisher=}} In 2010, [[Magnolia Pictures]] released his documentary adaptation of the New York Times Bestseller [[Freakonomics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/magazine/entrepreneur/2009/march/200014.html|title=A Better Way to Prepare|first=Dennis|last=Romero|date=10 February 2009|publisher=}} It was the Closing Night gala film at the 2010 [[Tribeca Film Festival]].[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118017025.html?categoryid=13&cs=1&nid=2562 ]{{dead link|date=July 2018}} In 2014, Troutwine's documentary, ''[[Print the Legend]]'', won a special jury award at the 2014 [[SXSW]] Film Festival. The film was distributed by [[Netflix]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/digital/news/netflix-acquires-3d-printing-documentary-print-the-legend-1201147547/|title=Netflix Acquires 3D Printing Documentary ‘Print the Legend’|first=Todd|last=Spangler|date=26 March 2014|publisher=}} In 2016, [[Business Insider]] published the Top 15 Netflix documentaries to "make you smarter about business", a list which included two of Troutwine's films: ''[[Print the Legend]]'' and ''[[Freakonomics#Film adaptation|Freakonomics]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/business-documentaries-on-netflix-watch-instantly-2016-1/|title=15 documentaries on Netflix that will make you smarter about business|publisher=}} ===Producer=== - ''[[Bill Nye: Science Guy]]'' (2017) (executive producer)
- ''[[Rolling Papers (film)|Rolling Papers]]'' (2015) (executive producer)
- ''[[Finders Keepers (2015 film)|Finders Keepers]]'' (2015) (executive producer)
- ''[[Print the Legend]]'' (2014) (producer)
- ''[[Jayhawkers (film)|Jayhawkers]]'' (2014) (executive producer)
- ''[[Gore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia]]'' (2013) (executive producer)
- ''[[Freakonomics#Film adaptation|Freakonomics]]'' (2010) (producer)
- ''[[Gerrymandering (film)|Gerrymandering]]'' (2010) (producer)
- ''[[Carissa]]'' (2008) (producer)
- ''[[Paris, je t'aime]]'' (2006) (executive producer)
- ''[[Lo Más bonito y mis mejores años]]'' (2005) (associate producer)
- ''[[Edmond (film)|Edmond]]'' (2005) (co-producer)
- ''[[The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things]]'' (2004) (executive producer)
- ''[[I Love Your Work]]'' (2003) (executive producer)
- ''[[Northfork]]'' (2003) (associate producer) Troutwine also appeared as himself in the 2007 independent film ''[[A Lawyer Walks into a Bar]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1311550/|title=Chad Troutwine|website=IMDb}} ==Personal life== On June 28, 2015, Troutwine married Sacha Radford at the [[Adamson House]] in [[Malibu, California|Malibu, CA]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blog.michaelsegalweddings.com/adamson-house-malibu-sacha-and-chad/|title=Adamson House, Malibu – Sacha and Chad » Michael Segal Photo Blog|website=www.blog.michaelsegalweddings.com}} ==See also== - [http://www.entrepreneur.com/magazine/entrepreneur/2009/march/200014.html Master Minds], an article on Troutwine and Moberg in the March 2009 issue of [[Entrepreneur magazine]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Troutwine, Chad}} [[Category:Business education]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:American chief executives of education-related organizations]] [[Category:Yale School of Management alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:John F.
