'''Operational Excellence''' is the execution of the business strategy more consistently and reliably than the competition. Operational Excellence is evidenced by results. Given two companies with the same strategy, the Operationally Excellent company will have lower operational risk, lower operating costs, and increased revenues relative to its competitors, creating value for customers and shareholders.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wilsonperumal.com/blog/a-better-definition-of-operational-excellence|title=A Better Definition of Operational Excellence|last=Soto|first=Francisco|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref> It may more simply be interpreted as "Execution Excellence."
Some interpretations of this [[management fad|management philosophy]] are based on earlier [[continuous improvement]] methodologies, such as [[Lean Thinking]], [[Six Sigma]], OKAPI and [[Scientific Management]]. However, the focus of Operational Excellence goes beyond the traditional event-based model of improvement toward a long-term change in organizational culture. Companies in pursuit of Operational Excellence do two things significantly differently than other companies: they manage their business and operational processes systematically and invest in developing the right culture.
Operational Excellence manifests itself through integrated performance across revenue, cost, and risk. It focuses on meeting customer expectation through the continuous improvement of the operational processes and the culture of the organization.
==Key Components== There are two components fundamental to Operational Excellence: an integrated [[Management system]] (IMS) and a culture of Operational Discipline.
The first component, the IMS, consists of a framework of processes and standards that define where the company is going, identify the risks to getting there, mitigate them, manage change, and continuously improve. Having one single, integrated management system reduces overlap, redundancy, and conflict. Early adopters of this practice have been companies such as [[Exxon]] and [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] utilizing Operations Integrity Management System (OIMS)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://corporate.exxonmobil.com/en/company/about-us/safety-and-health/operations-integrity-management-system|title=Learn about the Operations integrity Management System at ExxonMobil|work=ExxonMobil|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref> and Operations Excellence Management Systems (OEMS)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chevron.com/about/operational-excellence/oems|title=OEMS|last=Affairs|first=Chevron Policy, Government and Public|website=chevron.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref>, respectively.
The second component, a culture of Operational Discipline, is commonly described as doing the right thing, the right way, every time. This culture is built upon five guiding principles developed from the United States Nuclear Navy, a [[high reliability organization]]. Those principles are integrity, questioning attitude, level of knowledge, watch team backup, and formality. These values are used to identify the behaviors expected of each and every employee and how they support the organization's mission and outcomes.
==Shingo Prize==
The [[Shingo Prize for Operational Excellence|Shingo Prize]], an organization that recognizes success in the discipline, has identified ten key principles its award winners display:<ref>{{cite web|title=Shingo Prize - Model and Guidelines|url=http://www.shingoprize.org/model-guidelines.html}}</ref>
# Respect every individual # Lead with humility # Seek perfection # Assure quality at the source # Flow and pull value # Embrace scientific thinking # Focus on process # Think systemically # Create constancy of purpose # Create value for the customer
==OKAPI method==
The OKAPI method was created by Organizational Intelligence experts Iris Tsidon <ref>http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-israeli-female-entrepreneurs-visit-silicon-valley-1001168309</ref> and Maya Gal.<ref>https://women2.com/stories/2014/04/07/meet-the-female-cto-and-ceo-who-are-shaking-up-the-corporate-world-with-their-crowdsourcing-startup</ref> Their system incorporates the use of a methodology of SMART KPIs ([[key performance indicator]]s).
*S – Specific: the more precise the KPI, the greater its value, and the more correct the focus it provides us. It is important that the KPI direct us towards what we want to achieve. *M – Measurable: a KPI is supposed to measure actions, not behavior. *A – Achievable: challenging but attainable *R – Relevant: KPIs need to be relevant to the objective we want to achieve, and contribute in a significant way to the organization's success. *T– Timely: Every assignment must be scheduled with a defined time table for completion
The OKAPI method identifies the main challenges facing companies striving for operational excellence:
;Disconnect :People are not connected enough to the larger business needs; rather, they are motivated by professional considerations, without seeing the prices we pay in the commercial aspects. ;Lack of progress :The tasks truly important for the growth of the business are not progressing. People here work very hard and are very devoted to their work, however, the assignments we need to perform in order to grow the business are not given priority ;Unable to change to stay competitive :In a competitive market, you need the ability to adapt your management infrastructure to change. However, this process has to happen quickly and efficiently. Many organizations do not succeed in changing courses in time to keep up with their competition. ;Data is too complicated to understand easily :To receive a picture of the state of the company, you should not need to dig through intricate Excel reports. Complicated reports and their preparation consumes lots of valuable time. Creating a system to enable the receipt of a timely, readily available picture on a current basis will add a great deal of value. ;No coherent management plan :There are many people who think that systematic management is not important, or they do not use one because setting it up and following a plan is not one of their strong points and they pay too heavy a price for it. They get too involved in facilitating transactions, leading business development, and creating solutions to immediate problems in the company. Managers need to learn how to delegate responsibility for their own current management, so that others can work towards the shared objectives we have defined.
==Flawless Execution (FLEX) Methodology==
Also known as PBED (Plan-Brief-Execute-Debrief) the FLEX methodology is an iterative IMS designed by fighter pilots to achieve operational excellence in combat, the methodology was adapted to a business practice in 1998. Elements of the methodology are utilised in the agile manifesto commonly used by software developers. As an iterative process it values adaptation of strategy to real world influences through the practice of debriefing. Debriefing is a tool utilised by organisations to drive cultural change, specifically "Nameless and Rankless" where who are and what your position is in an organisation is irrelevant when assessing results and developing solutions:
*Plan - Establish a long term strategy focused on a common purpose. A High Definition Destination (HDD) then follow the six steps: 1. Set a clear, measurable and achievable team objective aligned to your HDD (alignment of the organisation) 2. Identify the threats and risks to achieving the objective (define to problem) 3. Identify the resources required to mitigate the threats (define the cost) 4. Apply lessons learned (*this is the key step for this method, taking a lesson from a debrief and applying it to the plan) 5. Develop individual objectives and tasks that align to the team objective (accountability) 6. Contingency plan. (three simple steps to recover from a major disruption) *Brief - Communicate the plan to the execution team *Execute - Execute the plan and focus on objectives (cultural change) *Debrief - Measure the result of daily execution vs the plan, conduct a root cause analysis and adapt the objectives (Step 4 of the six step planning process)
Philosophically individuals practising Operational Excellence within an organisation should champion simplicity over complexity. In practice this should see the self awareness exhibited around errors and mistakes in decision making be rewarded, on the basis the lesson is learned and applied, leading to continuous improvement of day to day practice and end result.

{{advert|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox university |name = '''Professional Risk Managers' International Association (PRMIA)''' |logo = Prmia logo.gif |established = 2002 |type = Nonprofit Professional Organization |purpose = Finance |city = [[Northfield, Minnesota]] |country = United States |website= {{url|http://www.prmia.org}} |}} {| class="wikitable floatright" | width="250" |- style="text-align:center;" | Organizational |- | Board of Directors *Justin McCarthy, Chair *Mihaela Capra *Oscar McMcarthy *Ken Radigan *Robert McWilliam *Robert R. Reitano *Wilson Fyffe *Jonathan Howitt *Pierre-Yves Maurois *Sanjay Sharma *Ken Yoo *Kraig Conrad Global Council *Chair Fahad Zafar *Carlos da Costa *Pierre-Yves Maurois *Dr. Ulrich Noegel *Monika Smatralova *Navin Sharma |} The '''Professional Risk Managers' International Association''' ('''PRMIA''') is a [[professional organization]] focused on the "promotion of sound [[risk management]] standards and practices globally", and "the integration of practice and theory";[http://www.prmia.org/about-us PRMIA Charter | Professional Risk Managers' International Association - PRMIA] it was founded in 2002 as a [[non-profit]]. See also under [[Financial Risk Manager#Dispute]], as well as [https://archive.today/20120909153518/http://www.riskglossary.com/link/garp_scandal.htm GARP Scandal: Global Association of Risk Professionals] It provides [[professional certification|certification and credentialing]] for professional [[risk manager]]s, as well as other educational programs and resources. ==Professional Risk Manager== The Professional Risk Manager (PRM) designation is an international [[professional certification]] offered by PRMIA.[http://www.prmia.org/?page=exam Home | Professional Risk Managers' International Association - PRMIA] The designation was first awarded in 2004. The PRM is an "independent validation" of skills within the [[financial risk management]] profession, additionally requiring a commitment to professional ethics. The PRM and the Global Association of Risk Professional's [[Financial Risk Manager|FRM]] are often compared as being the two definitive risk management designations in the industry. [https://web.archive.org/web/20160315024124/http://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304370304575152212605720290 Risk Managers Get Certified – As Profession Grows, Demand Increases for Standards-Setting Examinations.] (Archived), ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' (April 1, 2010)[http://news.efinancialcareers.com/za-en/1381/qualifications-which-are-neither-the-cfa-nor-the-mba-but-could-nevertheless-boost-your-career/ Beyond the CFA and MBA], efinancialcareers.com[https://www.institutionalinvestor.com/article/b1505qj433jnpj/the-rise-of-the-chief-risk-officer The Rise of the Chief Risk Officer], ''[[Institutional Investor (magazine)|Institutional Investor]]'' (March 2017). Candidates are required to pass four exams:
  1. Finance theory, financial instruments and financial markets (2 hours)
  2. Mathematical foundations of risk measurement (2 hours: [[calculus]], [[matrix algebra|matrix-]] and [[linear algebra]], [[probability]], [[statistics]], and [[numerical methods]])
  3. Risk management practices (3 hours: risk management frameworks [capital allocation, [[regulatory capital]], [[economic capital]], [[capital adequacy]]], [[operational risk]], [[credit risk]], [[counterparty credit risk]], [[market risk]], [[liquidity risk]], [[funds transfer pricing|FTP]], [[Asset liability management|ALM]])
  4. [[Case studies]], ''PRMIA standards of best practice, conduct and ethics'', bylaws (1 hour)
The exams are computer-based and the questions are all multiple choice; the passing grade is 60%. The exams can be taken in any order and must be completed over a period of up to two years; they are offered during four testing windows per year, each of three weeks.[http://www.prmia.org/sites/default/files/references/PRMCandidateGuide.pdf PRM Candidate Guidebook] Individual exam pass rates are 54% for Exam II, 59% for Exams I and III, and 78% for Exam IV;[http://www.prmia.org/prm-exam/faq#StructureQ8 FAQs][http://www.wallstreetmojo.com/prm-exam-profesisonal-risk-manager/ prm-exam], wallstreetmojo.com with an overall of just over 65%. The PRM program recognizes other professional designations and gives partial credit to "cross-over" candidates, as well as to graduates of select university programs. The recommended reading material is the seven volume ''Professional Risk Managers' Handbook'' edited and authored by various practitioners and academics,{{cite web|url=http://prmia.org/testsm/authors.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121174854/http://prmia.org/testsm/authors.php|archivedate=2012-01-21|title=PRMIA PRM Handbook - Author Biographies}} including [[Salih Neftci]] and [[Paul Wilmott]]. ''PRM Online Training'' is available for those who wish to access customized [[E-learning|online learning]]. Minimum experience requirements are:[http://www.prmia.org/prm-exam/exam-changes#experience1 prmia.org: Changes to the PRM Exam] four years without a [[bachelor's degree]]; two years for those with bachelor's degrees; no requirements for holders of a relevant [[graduate school|graduate degree]] (i.e. [[MBA]], [[Master of Finance|MSF]], [[Master of Quantitative Finance|MQF]] etc.) or of an accepted [[:Category:Professional certification in finance|professional designation]] ([[chartered financial analyst|CFA]], [[Chartered Alternative Investment Analyst|CAIA]], [[Certificate in Quantitative Finance|CQF]], etc.). To maintain the designation holder's are required to complete 20 "[[Continuing professional development|Continuing Risk Learning]]" credits each year, to renew their "Sustaining Membership", and to uphold the professional and ethical standards as defined by the ''PRMIA Standards of Best Practice, Conduct and Ethics''. ==Certificate programs== PRMIA offers various stand-alone certificate programs designed to give a "focused" and "practical" understanding of various areas of risk management.[http://www.prmia.org/certificate-programs Certificate Programs] As for the PRM, the passing score for these is 60%. The computerized tests are offered on all business days. To maintain certification one is required to uphold PRMIA’s professional and ethical standards. *The Associate PRM covers the core risk management concepts in a less mathematical fashion than the PRM, "allowing non-specialists to interpret risk management information and reports".[http://www.prmia.org/?page=exam&option=trainingAPRM Home | Professional Risk Managers' International Association - PRMIA] A single 3 hour exam is required; the recommended text is ''The Essentials of Risk Management'' ({{ISBN|0071429662}}). *The Operational Risk Manager Certificate prepares managers to "implement risk assessment initiatives, produce risk management information and understand basic modeling techniques". The exam is 2 hours duration. Preparation is the practitioner-authored ''Operational Risk Manager Certificate Handbook''. ''ORM Online Training'' is also available. *The Credit and Counterparty Risk Manager Certificate focuses on a practical understanding of credit risk analysis frameworks within financial institutions. The program is designed to be relevant to credit risk staff, as well as to [[Comptroller|financial controllers]], and [[Regulatory_compliance|compliance]] and legal officers. The exam is 2 hours duration. Preparation is the ''Credit and Counterparty Risk Manager Handbook''. *The Market, Liquidity and Asset Liability Management Risk Manager Certificate covers the areas of [[market risk]], [[liquidity risk]], and [[asset liability management]], and similarly focuses on application in financial institutions. The exam is 2 hours duration. Preparation is the ''Market, Liquidity and Asset Liability Management Risk Manager Handbook''. ==Education and professional development== PRMIA offers training and development programs in finance and risk management worldwide.[http://www.prmia.org/training/professional-development PRMIA Professional Development] In the classroom, these are through open enrollment courses, and through company-specific, in-house, customized training. Electronically, the offering comprises over 700 [[short course]]s and 20 professional courses, numerous live and recorded [[webinar]]s, as well other "Risk Resources". The association publishes the various books linked to its examination program, as well as others, and ''Intelligent Risk'', its quarterly newsletter.[http://www.prmia.org/risk-resources/prmia-publications PRMIA Publications ] ==See also== {| |- | valign="top" | '''Institutions''' *[[American Risk and Insurance Association]] *[[Asia Risk Management Institute]] (ARiMI) *[[Association of Insurance and Risk Managers in Industry and Commerce]] *Global Association of Risk Professionals *Institute of Risk Management *[[Risk and Insurance Management Society]] | valign="top" | '''Certifications''' *[[Certificate in Quantitative Finance]] (CQF) *[[Certified Risk Analyst]] (CRA) *[[Certified Risk Manager]] (CRM) *[[Institute and Faculty of Actuaries#Chartered Enterprise Risk Actuary .28CERA.29|Chartered Enterprise Risk Actuary]] (CERA; [[Institute and Faculty of Actuaries]] credential) *[[Chartered Enterprise Risk Analyst]] (CERA; [[Society of Actuaries]] credential) *[[Financial Risk Manager]] (FRM) *[[Institute of Risk Management#IRM Courses|International Diploma in Risk Management]] (MIRM designation; [[Enterprise Risk Management|ERM]] focused) |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.prmia.org}} * [http://www.prmia.org/sites/default/files/references/PRMIA_Standards_of_Best_Practice_Conduct__Ethics_4_1.pdf PRMIA Standards of Best Practice, Conduct and Ethics] *[http://www.prmia.org/chapters Individual Chapters:] ** [http://www.prmia.org/chapter/new-york New York Chapter] ** [http://www.prmia.org/chapter/vancouver Vancouver Chapter] ** [http://www.prmia.org/chapter/montreal Montreal Chapter] ** [http://www.prmia.org/chapter/london London Chapter] [[Category:Risk management in business]] [[Category:International professional associations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2002]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Minnesota]] [[Category:Northfield, Minnesota]] [[Category:Business and finance professional associations]]

{{Infobox person | name = Sam Altman | image = File:Sam Altman in 2009.jpg | caption = Altman in 2009 | birth_name = Samuel H. Altman | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1985|04|22|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[US]] | residence = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], [[US]]{{cite web|title=Sam Altman |url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/sam-altman#/entity |website=CrunchBase |publisher=[[TechCrunch]] |accessdate=4 April 2016 }} | nationality = American | citizenship = [[United States]] | alma_mater = [[Stanford University]] (dropped out) | occupation = [[Entrepreneur]] | known_for = [[Loopt]], [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]], [[OpenAI]] | networth = | title = President of [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] | spouse = | children = | website = {{Official URL}} | signature = }} '''Samuel H.''' "'''Sam'''" '''Altman''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɔː|l|t|m|ən}}; born April 22, 1985) is an American [[entrepreneur]], [[investor]], [[programmer]], and [[blog]]ger.{{cite web |url=http://blog.samaltman.com |title=Sam Altman |work=SamAltman.com |accessdate=December 15, 2015}} He is the president of [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] and co-chairman of [[OpenAI]].{{cite web |first=Paul |last=Graham |url=http://blog.ycombinator.com/sam-altman-for-president |title=Sam Altman for President |work=Y Combinator |date=April 24, 2014 |accessdate=March 20, 2017}}{{cite web | title=OpenAI | url=https://openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/ | accessdate=March 20, 2017}} ==Early life and education== Altman grew up in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], his mother was a dermatologist. He received his first computer at the age of 8,{{cite web |first=Tom |last=Junod |title=How Venture Capitalists Find Opportunities in the Future |url=http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/interviews/a30763/sam-altman-interview-2014/ |work=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |date=December 18, 2014 |accessdate=December 15, 2015}} He was raised Jewish and is gay.{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/10/10/sam-altmans-manifest-destiny|title=Sam Altman’s Manifest Destiny|website=NewYorker.com|publisher=The New Yorker|accessdate=17 May 2017}} He attended [[John Burroughs School]] for high school and studied computer science at [[Stanford University]] until dropping out in 2005.{{cite web |title=People |url=http://ycombinator.com/people.html |work=[[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] |accessdate=December 15, 2015}} While studying at Stanford, he worked in the [[Stanford Artificial Intelligence Lab|AI Lab]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/sam-altman#section-overview|title=Sam Altman - President, YC Group @ Y Combinator {{!}} Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase|language=en|access-date=2018-02-20}}. In 2017 he received an honorary degree from the [[University of Waterloo]].{{cite web | url=https://uwaterloo.ca/registrar/spring-2017-honorary-and-award-recipients | title=Spring 2017 honorary and award recipients | publisher=University of Waterloo | work=Registrar's Office | accessdate=July 7, 2017}} ==Career== ===Loopt=== In 2005, at age 19,{{cite web |first=Jason |last=Ankeny |title=Meet Y Combinator's Bold Whiz Kid Boss |url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/244508 |date=April 25, 2015 |accessdate=December 15, 2015}} Altman [[entrepreneur|co-founded]] and became [[chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Loopt]],{{cite web|url=http://www.loopt.com/about/company/executives |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216022416/http://www.loopt.com/about/company/executives/ |archive-date=February 16, 2012 |title=Executives |accessdate=December 15, 2015 |work=[[Loopt]]}} a location-based [[social networking service|social networking]] [[mobile software|mobile application]]. Loopt was shut down in 2012 after failing to get traction and was acquired by the [[Green Dot Corporation]] for more than $43 million.{{cite news | title=Startup Loopt Lands with Green Dot | date=March 9, 2012 | work=[[Wall Street Journal]] | url =https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2012/03/09/startup-loopt-lands-with-green-dot/| accessdate = March 13, 2012}}{{Cite news|url=https://mastersofscale.com/sam-altman-why-customer-love-is-all-you-need/|title=Sam Altman: Why customer love is all you need {{!}} Masters of Scale podcast|work=WaitWhat|access-date=2018-03-20|language=en-US}} ===Y Combinator=== Altman began as a part-time partner at [[Y Combinator]] in 2011.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/sam-altman#section-overview|title=Sam Altman - President, YC Group @ Y Combinator {{!}} Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase|language=en|access-date=2018-02-20}} In 2014, Altman was named president of Y Combinator, whose first batch of investments included Loopt.{{cite web |first=Paul |last=Graham |url=http://blog.ycombinator.com/sam-altman-for-president |title=Sam Altman for President |work=Y Combinator |date=April 24, 2014 |accessdate=December 15, 2015}} In a 2014 blog post, Altman said that the total valuation of Y Combinator companies had surpassed $65 billion, including well-known companies like [[Airbnb]], [[Dropbox (service)|Dropbox]], [[Zenefits]] and [[Stripe (company)|Stripe]].{{cite news|url=https://blog.ycombinator.com/yc-stats |accessdate=December 19, 2015|title=YC Stats | publisher=Y Combinator | date=August 26, 2015}} In September 2016, Altman announced that he would become president of YC Group, which includes Y Combinator and other units.{{cite web|first=Sam|last=Altman|url=https://blog.ycombinator.com/yc-changes|title=YC Changes |work=Y Combinator |accessdate=November 7, 2016}} Altman has said that he hopes to expand Y Combinator to fund 1,000 new companies per year. He has also tried to expand the types of companies funded by YC, especially 'hard technology' companies.{{cite news|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3044282/the-y-combinator-chronicles/california-dreamin |accessdate=July 22, 2015|title=Y Combinator President Sam Altman is Dreaming Big| website=Fast Company | date=April 16, 2015}} In October 2015, Altman announced YC Continuity, a $700 million growth-stage [[equity fund]] that invests in YC companies.{{cite news|url=http://blog.ycombinator.com/yc-continuity-fund |accessdate=December 19, 2015|title=YC Continuity | publisher=Y Combinator | date=October 15, 2015}}
- {{cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/10/15/y-combinator-raises-700m-to-keep-funding-yc-startups-as-they-mature/ |accessdate=December 19, 2015|title=YC Continuity | website=VentureBeat | date=October 15, 2015}} Also in October 2015, Altman announced Y Combinator Research, a non-profit research lab, and donated $10 million to the group.{{cite news|url=https://blog.ycombinator.com/yc-research | accessdate=February 19, 2016 | title=YC Research | publisher=Y Combinator | date=October 7, 2015}} YC Research has thus far announced research on basic income, the future of computing, education, and building new cities.{{cite web|title=Y Combinator Research|url=https://ycr.org/|website=YC Research|accessdate=3 August 2016}} Altman was named the top investor under 30 by ''[[Forbes]]'' in 2015,{{cite news | title= Forbes' 30 Under 30 2015: Venture Capital | date=January 5, 2015| url =https://www.forbes.com/30under30/#/venture-capital | work =[[Forbes]] | accessdate = February 28, 2015}} one of the "Best Young Entrepreneurs in Technology" by ''[[BusinessWeek]]'' in 2008{{cite news | title= Tech’s Best Young Entrepreneurs | date=April 18, 2008 | url =http://images.businessweek.com/ss/07/03/0326_tech_entrepreneurs/source/9.htm | work =[[BusinessWeek]] | accessdate = April 19, 2009}} and listed as one of the five most interesting startup founders between 1979 and 2009 by his colleague [[Paul Graham (computer programmer)|Paul Graham]].{{cite web|url=http://www.paulgraham.com/5founders.html |title=Five Founders |accessdate=April 19, 2009|authorlink=Paul Graham (computer programmer)|last=Graham |first=Paul |date=April 2009 }} ===Angel investing=== He is a personal investor in many companies, including [[Airbnb]], [[Stripe (company)|Stripe]], [[Reddit]], [[Asana_(software)|Asana]], [[Pinterest]], [[Teespring]], [[Zenefits]], FarmLogs, [[Shoptiques]], [[Instacart]], [[Optimizely]], [[Verbling]], [[Soylent_(drink)|Soylent]], Reserve, Vicarious, Clever, Notable PDF{{cite web|last1=Altman|first1=Sam|title=Angel List|url=https://angel.co/sama/syndicate|website=Angel List|publisher=|accessdate=April 20, 2015}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tech/s/notable-pdf-built-annotation-tool-130003639.html|title=How Notable PDF built an annotation tool for PDFs on the web|last=|first=|date=2017-04-05|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405210802/https://www.yahoo.com/tech/notable-pdf-built-annotation-tool-130003639.html|archive-date=2017-04-05|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-26}} and [[Change.org]].{{cite web|title=Change.org - Investors {{!}} CrunchBase|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/change-org/investors|website=CrunchBase|accessdate=3 August 2016}} He was the CEO of [[Reddit]] for eight days in 2014 after CEO [[Yishan Wong]] resigned.{{cite news|url=http://blog.samaltman.com/a-new-team-at-reddit |accessdate=February 13, 2015|title=A New Team At Reddit | publisher=Sam Altman | date=November 13, 2014}} As part of his investment, he developed a new way for the community to own part of the company. He announced the return of Steve Huffman as CEO on July 10, 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/comments/3cucye/ |title=An Old Team At Reddit |accessdate=July 13, 2015 |publisher=[[reddit]] }} ===Nuclear energy=== He is chairman of the board for [[Helion Energy|Helion]] and Oklo, two nuclear energy companies. He has said that nuclear energy is one of the most important areas of technological development.{{cite web|url=http://blog.samaltman.com/energy/ | title=Energy |accessdate=July 13, 2015 |publisher=Sam Altman }} ===OpenAI=== Altman and [[Elon Musk]] were the co-chairmen of [[OpenAI]]. OpenAI is a [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] whose goal is to advance digital intelligence in a way that is most likely to benefit humanity as a whole, rather than cause harm.{{cite web | title=OpenAI | url=https://openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/ | accessdate=December 15, 2015}} On February 21 2018, Elon Musk left [[OpenAI]]'s board to avoid any conflict of interest with [[Tesla, Inc.|Tesla]].{{cite web | title=Elon Musk Leaves OpenAI board | url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/21/17036214/elon-musk-openai-ai-safety-leaves-board | accessdate=February 21, 2018}} ==Teaching== In fall 2014, he taught a class at [[Stanford University]] called "[http://startupclass.samaltman.com/ How To Start a Startup]". Guest lecturers included [[Paul Graham (computer programmer)|Paul Graham]], [[Peter Thiel]], Adora Cheung, Alex Schultz, [[Marc Andreessen]], [[Ron Conway]], Carolynn Levy, Kirsty Nathoo, [[Ben Horowitz]], [[Brian Chesky]], [[Alfred Lin]], [[Aaron Levie]], [[Reid Hoffman]], Kevin Hale, [[Ben Silbermann]] and [[Emmett Shear]]. He currently teaches Y Combinator Startup School, a 10-week course featuring guests including Stewart Butterfield, Adam D'Angelo, and Dustin Moskovitz.{{cite web|url=https://www.startupschool.org/|website=Startup School |title= STARTUP SCHOOL BY Y COMBINATOR | access-date= April 25, 2017}} ==Writing== Altman occasionally posts to his [http://blog.samaltman.com blog], mostly about startups and technology. He also wrote [http://playbook.samaltman.com Startup Playbook], a distillation of advice that Y Combinator gives to its startups.{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Startup-Playbook-Sam-Altman-ebook/dp/B0181ZPASC|title=Startup Playbook|last=Altman|first=Sam|others=Gregory Koberger|language=English}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://blog.samaltman.com Altman's blog] (2010 to date) * [http://playbook.samaltman.com Startup Playbook] (2016) * [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/10/10/sam-altmans-manifest-destiny Sam Altman’s Manifest Destiny]. "Is the head of Y Combinator fixing the world, or trying to take over Silicon Valley?" By [[Tad Friend]] (October 2016), ''[[The New Yorker]]'' * [https://archive.is/20130126114430/http://www.inc.com/30under30/2007/4-altman.html Inc.: Top 30 Entrepreneurs Under 30 - Sam Altman, Loopt] (2007) * [http://tusb.stanford.edu/2007/05/sam_altman_founder_of_loopt.html Sam Altman - Founder of Loopt (the unofficial Stanford blog)] (2007) {{DEFAULTSORT:Altman, Sam}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American computer programmers]] [[Category:American Jews]] [[Category:Businesspeople in information technology]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category: LGBT people from Missouri]] [[Category: Gay men]] [[Category:Y Combinator people]]

'''Shaul Nehamia Eisenberg''' ({{lang-he|שאול אייזנברג}}; 1921–1997) was a [[Jewish]] [[businessperson|businessmen]] and a billionaire tycoon.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title= Shaul Eisenberg|work=[[Toledo Blade|"The Blade"]]| date= March 28, 1997| publisher= | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19970328&id=I7tAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BAQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5756,9829905| accessdate = March 20, 2013}}</ref>
==Early life==
Eisenberg was born in 1921 in [[Munich]] to a religious [[Jewish]] family from [[Poland]]. Shortly after the uprising of the [[Nazis]] in the government, he fled and wandered as a refugee around [[Europe]].<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title= BILLIONAIRE SHAUL EISENBERG DIES AT 76| date= March 27, 1997| publisher= | url = http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1997/Billionaire-Shaul-Eisenberg-dies-at-76/id-9e84d41efbf1c9c17bb8fcc450017c12| work = | pages = | accessdate = March 20, 2013}}</ref>
He later moved to Japan. In 1941, he married a local woman. During [[World War II]] he worked with industrial factories, associating with the [[Axis Power]] countries. After the war ended, he began working with [[United States|American]] businesses, importing iron products for the Japanese steel industry, when at the same time exporting a variety of Japanese-made products to [[India]].<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title= Shaul Eisenberg in a New York Times article| date= March 26, 1997| publisher= | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19970326&id=4jFdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HFsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1560,3799378| work = [[New York Times]]| pages = | accessdate = March 20, 2013}}</ref>
At the start of the 1950s, Eisenberg expanded his business to other countries in the Far East, especially [[South Korea]], where he invested money while mediating between the local authority to manufacturers from the East that were also doing business there. Among them were: [[British Electric]], [[Siemens]], [[MAN SE]], and [[Fiat Automobiles]]. Within a decade, he managed to mediate a vast variety of projects, such as developing production lines for recycled paper and purchasing airplanes and trains. He got an award from the Korean government for his actions. Until the mid-1960s, Eisenberg was the primary factor and catalyst in the commerce between South Korea and Japan to Western countries. He got high brokerage commissions, and therefore a few of which led to local and international scandals.<ref>{{cite news|first= |last= |coauthors= |authorlink= |title=Shaul Eisenberg on |date=1997-03-20 |publisher= |url=http://www.think-aboutit.com/conspiracy/ShaulEisenberg.htm |work= |pages= |accessdate= |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060508195528/http://www.think-aboutit.com/conspiracy/ShaulEisenberg.htm |archivedate=May 8, 2006 }}</ref>
==Eisenberg Law and his activity in Israel==
Eisenberg founded the company [[Israel Corporation]], and a new law was enacted for him, allowing the company to have a tax break for 30 years. The law, which got its nickname from Eisenberg, was meant to encourage [[entrepreneur]]s. Upon getting these benefits, Eisenberg began mimicking his international actions and do them in Israel as well, which led him to settle in [[Savyon]], Israel. With Israel Corporation he began purchasing some holdings in the companies [[Zim Integrated Shipping Services]], [[Oil Refineries]], and others.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | authors= |authorlink= | title= Eisenberg plans to concentrate in Israel. (Shaul Eisenberg) (Conglomerates)| date= April 18, 1990| publisher= | url = http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-9223380_ITM| work = | pages = | accessdate = March 20, 2013}}</ref>
At the same time he took advantage of his connections to do militant transactions between the Far East and Israel, and also became an exporter of weapons from Israel to countries in [[Africa]] and [[South America]]. Later on he was the first person to do commercial business between Israel and [[China]]. Eisenberg is considered a significant donor to political parties, influencing the [[Politics of Israel|Israeli politics]].<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | authors= Norman Kaplan|authorlink= | title= The Establishment of Diplomatic Relations between Israel and China:| date= | publisher= | url = http://www.calcol.com/history-15.html| work = | pages = | accessdate = March 20, 2013 }}</ref>
In 1979, Eisenberg founded "[[Beit Asia]]" in [[Tel Aviv]], which he also got special tax-cuts for, where he located his stock market investments' [[Headquarters|headquarter]], owned by Eisenberg’s Group. Jonathan Zohovsky, his daughter’s husband, as well as Michael Albin, who was the manager of the group, assisted him. After the [[1983 Israel bank stock crisis|Israeli 1983 stock market crash]], the group had significant losses, and later on the [[Israel Police|police]] found that the company had been hiding information from its stockholders and Albin was found guilty. He later died in tragic reasons, and Eisenberg disconnected his relationship with his daughter and her husband. In the 1990s, his business activity began to slow down, due to involvement of other markets in the Far East and other factors. Eisenberg died in [[Beijing]] in 1997, two years before the expiration of the Eisenberg Law.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | authors= Mitch Abrams|authorlink= | title= Israel industrialist Shaul Eisenberg dies| date= June 5, 1997| publisher= | url = http://www.jta.org/news/article/1997/06/05/3930/BIsraelindustrial| work = | pages = | accessdate = March 20, 2013}}</ref>
==Family==
Eisenberg's brother, Refael, who was a [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] scholar, died in 1976, leaving twelve children behind him.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{UPE|date=November 2017|pre16Jun2014=yes}} {{Infobox person | name = Shlomo Kalish | image = Shlomo Kalish.TIF | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1952}} | birth_place = Haifa, Israel | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Israel | other_names = | occupation = Hi-Tech Investor | known_for = Work in Mathematical Economics }}
'''Shlomo Kalish''', Ph.D., is the Founder and Managing Partner at Jerusalem Global Ventures.<ref name="Official Jerusalem Global Ventures Website">http://www.jgv.com/shlomo-kalish</ref> He is known as one of the first and most successful hi-tech investors in Israel.<ref name="Crunch Base">{{cite web|title=Shlomo Kalish|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/person/shlomo-kalish-2|publisher=Crunch Base|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref>
==Early life== Shlomo Kalish was born in 1952 in [[Haifa]], [[Israel]] to Issacher Dov and Haya Kalish- both Holocaust survivors.<ref name=Lifestyles>{{cite journal|last=Manfredi|first=P.S.|title=Dr. Shlomo Kalish|journal=Lifestyles Magazine|date=Winter 2004|volume=33|issue=194|pages=37–40}}</ref> Kalish served as a fighter pilot from 1971–1975, which included the [[Yom Kippur War]].<ref name=Mako>{{cite web|title=רב, מיליונר, טייס קרב, פרופסור: הכירו את החב"דניק של תעשיית ההיי-טק|url=http://www.mako.co.il/men-money/israeli-millionaires/Article-36c368beabfea31006.htm|publisher=Mako|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref>
==Education== In 1977, Kalish received a B.Sc. in Mathematics from [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref name=Lifestyles /> He completed an M.Sc. and a PhD at [[MIT]]'s Sloan School <ref name="Business Week">{{cite web|title=Shlomo Kalish Ph.D.|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=111039&ticker=CYRP|publisher=Business Week|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref> In 1981 he began teaching at the [[University of Rochester]]. In 1985 he joined the Management Faculty of [[Tel Aviv University]],<ref name="Lifestyles"/> and established a hi-tech consulting business.<ref name=Mako />
==Career== In 1999 Kalish founded Jerusalem Global Ventures, a Jerusalem-based VC.<ref name="Crunch Base" /> Kalish also served as General Partner of Concord Ventures I, LP from 1997-1999.<ref name="Business Week" /> Dr. Kalish led investments in Saifun Semiconductors, Oridion Medical, Oren Semiconductors, Creo, QXL, Mellanox Technologies, Picturevision and Galileo.<ref name=CalCalist>{{cite web|title=הרב שלמה קליש מסתער על ההייטק הישראלי|url=http://www.calcalist.co.il/internet/articles/0,7340,L-3581496,00.html|publisher=CalCalist|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref> In 1999, Kalish also founded Yazam.com, one of the first accelerators aimed at internet projects in Israel.<ref name=Mako /> Yazam was later sold to U.S. Technologies.
In 2007, Kalish was ranked number 39 on the Forbes [[Midas List]],<ref name=Forbes>{{cite web|title=#39 Shlomo Kalish|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2007/99/biz_07midas_Schlomo-Kalish_ITPF.html|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref> and first for the Israelis on the list by [[Forbes Magazine]]. Kalish was a Managing Partner at Vaizra Israel from 2010-2016,<ref name="Official Jerusalem Global Ventures Website"/> a division of Vaizra Investments. Vaizra was founded by Yitzhak (Viatcheslav) Mirilashvili, a former founder of [[VKontakte]].<ref name="CalCalist"/>
==Community== Shlomo Kalish is a board member at the charity Shalom Beineinu, which he founded.<ref name="Shalom Beinenu">{{cite web|title=Shlomo Kalish|url=http://www.shalombeinenu.org/hebrew/members.html|publisher=Shalom Beinenu|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref> He is also on the Board of Trustees of the Jerusalem College of Technology and the Technion Israel Institute of Technology.<ref name="Forbes"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
